cheatSheets.title: Security Acronyms
cheatSheets.description: Master list of security acronyms and abbreviations
cheatSheets.content: CIA=Confidentiality Integrity Availability. AAA=Authn Authz Accounting. SIEM=Security Info & Event Mgmt. SOAR=Security Orchestration Automation Response. EDR/XDR=Endpoint/Extended Detection Response. IDS/IPS=Intrusion Detection/Prevention. MFA=Multi-Factor Auth. PKI=Public Key Infrastructure. DLP=Data Loss Prevention. NAC=Network Access Control. RAID=Redundant Array; in security often Risk Assessment. BCP/DR=Business Continuity/Disaster Recovery.

cheatSheets.title: CIA Triad & Security Controls
cheatSheets.content: Confidentiality: keep data private (encryption, access controls). Integrity: data accurate and unaltered (hashing, digital signatures). Availability: data and systems accessible when needed (redundancy, backups). Controls: Technical (firewall, MFA), Administrative (policies, training), Physical (locks, guards).

cheatSheets.title: Authentication vs Authorization
cheatSheets.content: Authentication = proving identity (who you are): something you know (password), have (token, phone), are (biometric). Authorization = what you're allowed to do (permissions, RBAC). MFA uses â‰¥2 factors. Single Sign-On (SSO) = one login for many apps; federated identity (SAML, OAuth).

cheatSheets.title: Attack Types & Mitigations
cheatSheets.content: Phishing: user training, email filtering, DMARC. DDoS: rate limiting, scrubbing, CDN. MitM: TLS, certificate pinning. SQLi/XSS: input validation, parameterized queries, CSP. Ransomware: backups, segmentation, EDR. Social engineering: awareness training, verification procedures.

cheatSheets.title: Encryption Standards
cheatSheets.content: Symmetric: AES (strong), 3DES (legacy). Asymmetric: RSA, ECC. Hashing: SHA-256/SHA-3 (secure), MD5/SHA-1 (avoid for new use). Key exchange: Diffie-Hellman. Digital signatures: RSA or ECDSA with hash. TLS uses asymmetric for key exchange, symmetric for bulk encryption.

glossary.definition: Security Information and Event Management - Centralized platform for collecting, correlating, and analyzing security logs and events in real-time.
Indicator of Compromise - Forensic data that identifies potentially malicious activity on a system or network (IPs, domains, file hashes, etc.).
Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response - Platform that automates security operations tasks and incident response workflows.
Endpoint Detection and Response - Security solution that monitors endpoint devices for threats and provides investigation and remediation capabilities.
Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures - The behavior patterns used by threat actors, as categorized in frameworks like MITRE ATT&CK.
Technique where an attacker moves through a network after initial compromise to access additional systems and escalate privileges.
Command and Control - Infrastructure used by attackers to communicate with and control compromised systems.
Regular communication pattern between malware and its C2 server, often at predictable intervals.
Techniques attackers use to maintain access to a system across reboots and credential changes.
Exploiting vulnerabilities or misconfigurations to gain higher-level permissions than initially granted.
Packet Capture - File format for storing network traffic data, commonly analyzed with Wireshark.
Globally-accessible knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations.
Unique identifier for Windows event log entries, used to categorize and filter security events.
Search Processing Language - Splunk's query language for searching and analyzing log data.
Alert triggered by legitimate activity incorrectly identified as malicious.
Average time between when an incident occurs and when it is detected by security teams.
Average time from detecting an incident to fully containing and resolving it.
Social engineering attack using fraudulent communications to trick recipients into revealing sensitive information or installing malware.
Vulnerability unknown to the software vendor, often exploited before a patch is available.
Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures - Standardized identifier for known security vulnerabilities.
Command Line Interface - Text-based interface for interacting with a computer by typing commands. Essential skill for SOC analysts to quickly perform tasks without GUI.
Program that interprets and executes commands in a CLI. Common shells include Bash (Linux/Mac), PowerShell (Windows), and Zsh. Each has its own syntax and features.
Bourne Again Shell - Default shell on most Linux systems. Used for scripting, automation, and log analysis in SOC work. Syntax: command [options] [arguments]
Microsoft's command shell and scripting language. Critical for Windows security analysis, Active Directory queries, and Windows Event Log investigation.
Application that provides access to a shell. Modern terminals support tabs, search, and color coding. Examples: Windows Terminal, iTerm2, GNOME Terminal.
Command-line tool for searching text patterns in files. Essential for log analysis. Example: 'grep "failed login" auth.log' finds all failed login attempts.
Shell operator that sends output from one command as input to another. Example: 'cat log.txt | grep error | wc -l' counts error lines. Fundamental for chaining commands.
Command that executes another command with administrator privileges on Linux/Mac. Example: 'sudo tail /var/log/secure' reads protected system logs. Use carefully.
Standard Input/Output/Error - Data streams in Unix-like systems. stdin: input to command, stdout: normal output, stderr: error messages. Redirect with >, <, 2>
Regular Expression - Pattern-matching language for searching text. Used in grep, log analysis, and SIEM queries. Example: '[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}' matches IPs.

categories.title: Windows Event IDs
categories.description: Master the most important security event codes

drills.question: What does Event ID 4625 indicate?
drills.explanation: Event ID 4625 indicates a failed logon attempt - critical for detecting brute force attacks and credential stuffing.

drills.question: Event ID 4672 indicates what?
drills.explanation: Event ID 4672 shows when special privileges are assigned to a new logon - useful for detecting privilege escalation.

drills.question: What does Event ID 4688 track?
drills.explanation: Event ID 4688 tracks new process creation - essential for detecting malicious execution and lateral movement.

drills.question: Event ID 7045 indicates what activity?
drills.explanation: Event ID 7045 indicates a new service was installed - common persistence mechanism for attackers.

drills.question: What does Event ID 4624 mean?
drills.explanation: Event ID 4624 indicates a successful account logon - correlate with 4625 to identify successful brute force attempts.

drills.question: What service typically runs on port 445?
drills.explanation: Port 445 is used for SMB (Server Message Block) - commonly targeted for lateral movement and ransomware.

drills.question: Which port is used for RDP?
drills.explanation: Port 3389 is Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) - frequently attacked and should be monitored for brute force attempts.

drills.question: Port 22 is associated with which service?
drills.explanation: Port 22 is SSH (Secure Shell) - watch for brute force attacks and unusual login patterns.

drills.question: What commonly runs on port 443?
drills.explanation: Port 443 is HTTPS - encrypted web traffic. Monitor for C2 communications hiding in HTTPS.

drills.question: Port 53 is used for what?
drills.explanation: Port 53 is DNS - watch for DNS tunneling, excessive queries, and queries to suspicious domains.

drills.question: Which MITRE tactic does 'Pass the Hash' fall under?
drills.explanation: Pass the Hash (T1550.002) is a Lateral Movement technique used to authenticate using NTLM hashes.

drills.question: Phishing falls under which tactic?
drills.explanation: Phishing (T1566) is an Initial Access technique - the attacker's first foothold into the environment.

drills.question: What tactic is 'Scheduled Task' associated with?
drills.explanation: Scheduled Task (T1053) is commonly used for Persistence to maintain access across reboots.

drills.question: Command and Control typically involves what?
drills.explanation: Command and Control (C2) is how attackers communicate with compromised systems to issue commands and receive data.

drills.question: Which is an Exfiltration technique?
drills.explanation: Exfiltration over C2 Channel (T1041) is how attackers steal data using their command and control infrastructure.

drills.question: What's suspicious about this Apache log?
drills.explanation: The '../..' pattern indicates a directory traversal attack attempting to access /etc/passwd outside the web root.

drills.log:

Feb 10 14:30:03 server sshd[1235]: Failed password for admin from 203.0.113.50 port 52892 ssh2
Feb 10 14:30:05 server sshd[1236]: Accepted password for admin from 203.0.113.50 port 52893 ssh2
drills.explanation: Rapid failed attempts followed by successful login indicates a successful brute force attack.

drills.question: What's happening in this log pattern?
drills.explanation: Successful login followed immediately by admin panel access suggests potential account compromise or insider threat.

drills.question: What type of IOC is '52.12.34.56'?
drills.explanation: This is an IPv4 address - can be checked against threat intelligence feeds like AbuseIPDB.

drills.question: What is '5d41402abc4b2a76b9719d911017c592'?
drills.explanation: This is an MD5 hash (32 hex characters) - used to identify files. MD5 hashes can be checked on VirusTotal.

drills.question: Which IOC type is 'malicious-site.com'?
drills.explanation: This is a domain name - check reputation on VirusTotal, URLScan.io, or Cisco Talos.

drills.question: What is 'http://evil.com/payload.exe'?
drills.explanation: This is a full URL (includes protocol and path) - scan with URLScan.io or submit to sandboxes.

drills.question: Which indicates possible lateral movement?

drills.question: What is a 'baseline' in threat hunting?
drills.explanation: Baseline = normal activity; hunting looks for deviations (anomalies) from baseline.

drills.question: SPL: how do you pipe results into a second search?
drills.explanation: Subsearch [ search index=main ... ] runs first; its output is used in the outer search.

drills.question: Which Linux command is often used for log analysis?
drills.explanation: grep filters lines; combined with awk/sed/cut it's common for ad-hoc log analysis.

drills.question: High volume of DNS queries to one domain from one host suggests?
drills.explanation: Unusual DNS volume or repeated queries to unknown domains can indicate DNS tunneling or beaconing.

projectsWalkthrough.intro: Welcome to my CyberSecurity-Projects repo. This is a collection of hands-on labs, case-style writeups, templates, and practice tools organized the way I actually study. Use this walkthrough to recreate the projects, understand the workflow, and reuse the same structure for your own SOC training.

steps.title: 1) Start with the SOC OS mindset
steps.body: This repo isn't just a portfolio â€” it's a practice environment. Pick one goal (detect, investigate, document, automate), then use the SOC OS apps (Templates, IOC Helper, Runbooks, Tickets, Log Viewer) to complete the work like a real analyst.

steps.title: 2) Choose a project track
steps.body: Use Projects â†’ Walkthroughs to pick a track: Network Analysis (Wireshark/PCAP), Log Analysis (Splunk/Syslog), Threat Intel, Cloud Security, or Web App Security (Docker lab). Each track has a goal, prerequisites, steps, and a final deliverable.

steps.title: 3) Recreate the lab environment
steps.body: Every project starts with setup: tools installed, a dataset/log/PCAP to analyze, and an isolated environment if it's a vulnerable app. If something is risky, keep it local (VM/Docker) and never expose it to the public internet.

steps.title: 4) Follow the investigation workflow
steps.body: For each project: collect evidence â†’ triage â†’ identify indicators â†’ validate with multiple sources â†’ document findings. Use Templates to write notes and final reports. Use IOC Helper to enrich indicators.

steps.title: 5) Produce a clean deliverable
steps.body: Each project should end with a README-style writeup: objective, environment, steps taken, evidence, results, and lessons learned. Bonus points if you include screenshots, example queries, and a short 'what I'd do next in a real SOC' section.

steps.title: 6) Turn it into repeatable practice
steps.body: After you finish once, you should be able to redo it faster. Add it to Tickets as a scenario, add key commands to CLI Cheats, add the best queries to Quick Reference, and store any sample logs/PCAPs in Lab Files.

steps.title: 7) Pick the next upgrade
steps.body: Upgrade paths: automate a step with a small script, add detection logic (Sigma/Splunk query), build a runbook, or create a new ticket scenario based on what you learned. The repo grows as your workflow improves.

prereqs: Basic understanding of IP addresses

wireshark.objective: Capture and analyze real network traffic using Wireshark. Identify DNS lookups, TCP handshakes, HTTP requests, and suspicious patterns. Document findings with screenshots and export PCAP evidence.

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Install Wireshark + Packet Capture Driver
steps.body:
Goal: Get Wireshark installed and ensure packet capture actually works.

---

## Windows Setup (Recommended for beginners)

1. Download Wireshark from:
https://www.wireshark.org/download.html

2. During installation, make sure you install:
- Wireshark
- Npcap (this is REQUIRED)

Npcap is the driver that allows packet capture.

### Important Install Options (Npcap)
When installing Npcap, enable:
- "Install Npcap in WinPcap API-compatible Mode" (recommended)

---

## Linux Setup

### Debian/Ubuntu/Kali
Run:

sudo apt update
sudo apt install wireshark

If asked about allowing non-root users to capture packets, select YES.

Then run:

sudo usermod -aG wireshark $USER

Log out and log back in.

---

## Validation
Open Wireshark.

You should see network interfaces listed (Wi-Fi, Ethernet, etc.).

If Wireshark shows "No interfaces found" on Windows:
- Npcap is missing or broken.

---

## Troubleshooting

### Issue: "No interfaces found"
Fix:
- Reinstall Npcap
- Reboot
- Run Wireshark as Administrator

### Issue: Permission denied (Linux)
Fix:
- Make sure you added your user to wireshark group
- Log out and log back in

---

Deliverable for this step:
- Screenshot of Wireshark showing at least one available interface.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Choose the Correct Network Interface
steps.body:
Goal: Capture traffic from the interface that actually has activity.

---

## How to Choose
Open Wireshark.

Look at the main screen where it lists interfaces.

You want the one that shows live activity spikes.

Common choices:
- Wi-Fi (most common)
- Ethernet
- VPN adapter (if you're using VPN)

---

## Quick Test Capture
1. Double click your interface
2. Wait 5â€“10 seconds
3. Stop capture (red square button)

If you captured packets, you're good.

---

## Validation
You should see:
- Packets scrolling during capture
- A packet count greater than 0 after stopping

---

## Troubleshooting

### Issue: No packets captured
Fix:
- Make sure you picked the right interface
- Try opening a browser tab and refreshing
- Disable VPN temporarily
- Run Wireshark as Admin

---

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing the interface you selected and packets captured.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Perform a Controlled Capture (DNS + Web Traffic)
steps.body:
Goal: Generate predictable traffic so your analysis is repeatable.

---

## Start a New Capture
1. Click Capture â†’ Start
2. Begin recording traffic

---

## Generate Traffic
Open your browser and visit these sites (in order):
- http://example.com
- https://google.com
- https://wikipedia.org

Then run a ping test:

### Windows (PowerShell)
ping 8.8.8.8

### Linux

Wireshark-Packet-Capture/captures/controlled_capture.pcapng

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Identify DNS Requests and Responses
steps.body:
Goal: Understand how DNS resolution appears in packet captures.

---

## Apply Filter
dns

---

## What to Look For
You should see packets like:
- Standard query A example.com
- Standard query response

Click one DNS packet.

Then expand:
Domain Name System (query)

Look for:
- Query Name
- Query Type (A, AAAA)
- Response IP address

---

## SOC Analyst Notes
DNS is often used in:
- Malware command-and-control callbacks
- Data exfiltration (DNS tunneling)
- Phishing site lookups

Suspicious indicators include:
- Long random domain names
- Many requests to unknown domains
- Requests to newly registered domains

---

## Validation
You should be able to answer:
- What domain was requested?
- What IP was returned?

---

Wireshark-Packet-Capture/analysis/dns-notes.md

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Analyze the TCP Handshake (SYN / SYN-ACK / ACK)
steps.body:
Goal: Identify the TCP 3-way handshake and understand what it means.

---

## Apply Filter
tcp.flags.syn == 1

This shows SYN packets.

---

## What to Look For
Click a SYN packet.

Look for:
- Source IP
- Destination IP
- Source Port
- Destination Port

Common ports:
- 80 (HTTP)
- 443 (HTTPS)

---

## Follow the Stream
Right click the packet â†’ Follow â†’ TCP Stream

This shows the full conversation.

---

## SOC Analyst Notes
SYN scanning is used by attackers.
If you see many SYN packets without responses, it can indicate:
- Port scan
- Recon activity

---

## Validation
You should be able to identify:
- A connection attempt
- Whether it succeeded

---

Write a short note in:
Wireshark-Packet-Capture/analysis/tcp-notes.md

Include:
- Source IP
- Destination IP
- Ports involved
- Whether the handshake completed

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Extract HTTP Request Details
steps.body:
Goal: Inspect HTTP requests and understand why HTTP is dangerous.

http

http://neverssl.com

## What to Look For

Expand:
Hypertext Transfer Protocol

- Host
- User-Agent
- Request URI
- Method (GET/POST)

---

## SOC Analyst Notes
HTTP is unencrypted.
If credentials are sent in plain text, they may be visible.

Attackers can:
- sniff passwords
- inject malicious payloads

## Validation

- the website host
- the URL path requested
- your user-agent string

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Analyze TLS Traffic (HTTPS)
steps.body:
Goal: Understand what HTTPS looks like and what can still be learned even when encrypted.

---

## Apply Filter

(or try)

## What to Look For
You should see:
- Client Hello
- Server Hello
- Certificate

Click a TLS packet.

Expand:
Transport Layer Security

- Server Name Indication (SNI)

Even if traffic is encrypted, analysts can still see:
- IP addresses
- domains (via SNI)
- certificate issuer
- timing / beacon patterns

---

## Validation
You should be able to identify:
- domain being contacted
- destination IP

---

## Deliverables
Screenshot showing:

Write short notes in:
Wireshark-Packet-Capture/analysis/tls-notes.md

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Detect Suspicious Patterns (Port Scans & Beaconing)
steps.body:
Goal: Learn basic SOC detection techniques inside Wireshark.

---

## Possible Suspicious Indicators

### Many SYN packets
Use:

tcp.flags.syn == 1 and tcp.flags.ack == 0

If you see one source IP hitting many destination ports quickly, that suggests scanning.

---

### Repeated connections to the same host (beaconing)
Use:

ip.addr == X.X.X.X

Replace with an IP from your capture.

Then look for repeated connections at consistent intervals.

---

### Strange DNS requests
Use:

dns.qry.name contains ".xyz"

or

dns.qry.name matches "[a-z0-9]{20,}"

---

## Validation
You should be able to identify at least ONE thing that could be suspicious.
Even if it's normal traffic, explain why.

---

## Deliverables
Write a short report:

Wireshark-Packet-Capture/analysis/suspicious-findings.md

Include:
- suspicious indicator
- evidence (packet number)
- why it may be suspicious
- alternative explanation

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Pick your lab layout (Universal)
steps.body:
Goal: Get syslog from rsyslog into Splunk.

Recommended universal layout:
- Splunk runs on your host (Windows/macOS/Linux) OR a Splunk Docker container.
- rsyslog runs on a Linux VM (or Linux host) and forwards logs to Splunk.

You need:
- Splunk reachable from the rsyslog machine.
- One of these ingestion methods:
  A) Network input (UDP 514 recommended for syslog)
  B) File monitor (Splunk monitors /var/log/* locally)

Validation:
- You can open Splunk Web in a browser (default: http://<splunk-host>:8000).
- You know the Splunk host IP that the rsyslog box can reach.

Troubleshooting:
- If you donâ€™t know IPs: run `ip a` (Linux) or `ipconfig` (Windows) to identify the right interface.
- If youâ€™re using a VM: make sure networking is set to Bridged or NAT with correct port access.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Install Splunk (choose one path)
steps.body:
Choose ONE:

Path A (Linux install):
1) Download Splunk Enterprise for Linux from Splunk.
2) Install and start Splunk.
3) Enable boot-start and accept license.

Path B (Docker):
Use Splunkâ€™s official container.
Example:
- Pull image and run Splunk exposing ports 8000 (web) and 8089 (mgmt) and your syslog port (514/udp).

Validation:
- Splunk Web loads.
- You can log in.

Troubleshooting:
- If Splunk Web wonâ€™t load, confirm the service/container is running and port 8000 is reachable.
- On Linux install, check: `sudo /opt/splunk/bin/splunk status`.
- On Docker, check: `docker ps` and container logs.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Create a dedicated syslog index in Splunk
steps.body:
In Splunk Web:
Settings â†’ Indexes â†’ New Index
Create an index like:
- Name: linux_syslog
- Type: Events
- Default settings are fine.

Why: A dedicated index keeps your lab clean and makes searches faster and more readable.

Validation:
- Settings â†’ Indexes shows linux_syslog exists.
- You can run: `| eventcount summarize=false index=linux_syslog` (should return 0 for now).

Troubleshooting:
- If you donâ€™t have permission, you may be logged in as a restricted user. Use admin for lab builds.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Configure Splunk to listen for syslog (UDP 514 recommended)
steps.body:
In Splunk Web:
Settings â†’ Data Inputs â†’ UDP â†’ New
- Port: 514 (or a high port like 1514 if you canâ€™t use 514)
- Sourcetype: syslog
- Index: linux_syslog

If you choose a high port (1514), you must forward to that port from rsyslog.

Validation:
- Data Inputs shows your UDP input is enabled.
- On the Splunk host, confirm listening:
  - Linux: `sudo ss -lunp | grep -E ':(514|1514)\b'`

Troubleshooting:
- Port 514 requires admin/root on many systems.
- If 514 is blocked by policy, use 1514.
- If youâ€™re on Cloudflare/Pages for the site: this lab is local; Cloudflare doesnâ€™t matter here.

steps.title: Step 5 â€” (If needed) Open firewall rules on the Splunk host
steps.body:
On the Splunk host, allow inbound UDP for your syslog port.

Linux (UFW examples):
- `sudo ufw allow 514/udp`
- or `sudo ufw allow 1514/udp`
- `sudo ufw status`

Windows:
- Create an inbound firewall rule for UDP 514 or 1514.

Validation:
From the rsyslog machine (Linux), test reachability (UDP is tricky to â€œpingâ€, but you can still sanity check):
- Confirm you can reach Splunk Web: `curl -I http://<splunk_ip>:8000`

Troubleshooting:
- If Splunk Web isnâ€™t reachable, fix basic network routing first.
- If only syslog fails, itâ€™s usually firewall/port mismatch.

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Install and verify rsyslog on Linux
steps.body:
On the Linux syslog source machine (VM or host):

Install:
- Debian/Ubuntu: `sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y rsyslog`
- RHEL/CentOS: `sudo yum install -y rsyslog` or `sudo dnf install -y rsyslog`

Verify service:
- `systemctl status rsyslog --no-pager`
- `logger "SOCOS test message: rsyslog is alive"`

Validation:
- `systemctl is-active rsyslog` returns `active`.
- The test message appears locally:
  - `sudo tail -n 50 /var/log/syslog` (Debian/Ubuntu)
  - `sudo tail -n 50 /var/log/messages` (RHEL/CentOS)

Troubleshooting:
- If `logger` works but file doesnâ€™t update, your distro may route logs via journald; still fineâ€”rsyslog can forward.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Configure rsyslog forwarding to Splunk UDP input
steps.body:
Create a forwarding config:

1) Identify Splunk host IP and port:
- Splunk IP: <splunk_ip>
- Port: 514 or 1514

2) Add rsyslog rule (common approach):
- Create a file like: `/etc/rsyslog.d/60-splunk-forward.conf`

Example forwarding line (UDP):
- `*.* @<splunk_ip>:514`
Or if using 1514:
- `*.* @<splunk_ip>:1514`

Notes:
- Single `@` = UDP
- Double `@@` = TCP

3) Restart rsyslog:
- `sudo systemctl restart rsyslog`

4) Send a test event:
- `logger "SOCOS test message: forwarding to Splunk"`

Validation (Splunk side):
In Splunk Search:
- `index=linux_syslog "SOCOS test message"`
You should see your event.

Troubleshooting:
- If nothing arrives:
  - Verify port matches the Splunk data input.
  - Confirm Splunk host is listening (`ss -lunp`).
  - Temporarily disable firewall to test.
  - Try TCP (`@@`) + Splunk TCP input if UDP is blocked.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Confirm parsing/sourcetype and set useful field expectations
steps.body:
In Splunk Search, explore your inbound syslog:
- `index=linux_syslog | head 20`

Look for:
- host
- source
- sourcetype (should be syslog)
- _time (timestamp is parsing correctly)

If timestamps look wrong:
- In Settings â†’ Data Inputs, confirm sourcetype syslog.
- You can also create a custom sourcetype later, but donâ€™t overcomplicate the lab.

Validation:
- Events have reasonable timestamps.
- host field matches your Linux VM/host.

Troubleshooting:
- If _time is current for all events, Splunk may not be extracting timestamps. Keep going anyway; your dashboard can still work, but note it in your write-up.

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Build your â€œinvestigation-gradeâ€ SPL searches (save 3â€“5)
steps.body:
Create a few searches youâ€™ll reuse in panels and as â€œdetections.â€ Here are SOC-style examples you can adapt.

1) Authentication failures (common):
- `index=linux_syslog ("Failed password" OR "authentication failure" OR "Invalid user")`

2) Successful logins:
- `index=linux_syslog ("Accepted password" OR "session opened")`

3) SSH activity focus:
- `index=linux_syslog (sshd OR "ssh") | stats count by host, source, user`

4) Sudo / privilege escalation hints:
- `index=linux_syslog ("sudo" AND ("COMMAND=" OR "session opened"))`

5) Top talkers / noisy sources:
- `index=linux_syslog | stats count by host, source | sort -count`

Save searches:
In Splunk, after running a search:
Save As â†’ Report
Name them clearly (e.g., SOCOS - Auth Failures).

Validation:
- Each saved search reruns successfully.
- You can open Reports and see them listed.

Troubleshooting:
- If your syslog doesnâ€™t include sshd/auth lines, generate some activity intentionally (log in/out via SSH, run sudo commands) and re-check.

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Create the dashboard (panels that tell a story)
steps.body:
Dashboards should prove skills: triage â†’ investigate â†’ summarize.

In Splunk Web:
Dashboards â†’ Create New Dashboard
Name: SOCOS - Syslog Monitoring (or similar)

Suggested panels (simple but impressive):
1) Events over time:
- `index=linux_syslog | timechart count`

2) Top sources:
- `index=linux_syslog | stats count by source | sort -count | head 10`

3) Auth failures over time:
- `index=linux_syslog ("Failed password" OR "Invalid user") | timechart count`

4) Top usernames targeted:
- `index=linux_syslog ("Failed password" OR "Invalid user") | rex "user (?<user>\w+)" | stats count by user | sort -count`

5) Sudo activity:
- `index=linux_syslog sudo | stats count by host, user | sort -count`

Validation:
- Dashboard loads and panels render.
- Panels show data from linux_syslog.

Troubleshooting:
- If regex extraction fails in panel 4, remove the rex and just group by raw patterns or use `table _raw` to inspect your log format.

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Export evidence: screenshots + dashboard XML + search notes
steps.body:
This is the portfolio part.

1) Screenshots:
- Capture the full dashboard + 2â€“3 individual panels.
- Capture 1â€“2 key searches that demonstrate investigation logic.

2) Export dashboard XML:
- Open the dashboard
- Edit â†’ Source (or Edit Dashboard â†’ Source)
- Copy XML into your repo (recommended path):
  - `Log-Analysis/dashboard/`
  - Save as: `socos-syslog-dashboard.xml`

3) Save SPL queries:
- Save a markdown file:
  - `Log-Analysis/notes/spl-queries.md`
  - Include each query + what it detects.

Validation:
- Files exist in those repo folders.
- XML opens and looks like Splunk dashboard XML.

Troubleshooting:
- If your Splunk UI hides â€œSource,â€ you may be in a restricted dashboard editor mode. Try classic dashboard editor or ensure admin permissions.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Write the mini incident narrative (SOC-style summary)
steps.body:
Create a short write-up so a recruiter understands what theyâ€™re seeing.

In your repo:
- `Log-Analysis/README.md` (or `Log-Analysis/report.md`)

Include:
- Purpose: what you monitored (syslog) and why.
- Data flow diagram (one paragraph is fine): rsyslog â†’ Splunk UDP input â†’ index.
- What you looked for: auth failures, ssh patterns, privilege escalation, noise sources.
- What you found: even if itâ€™s â€œbaseline normal,â€ explain what normal looks like.
- Next steps: how youâ€™d alert (thresholds, scheduled searches, notable events).

Validation:
- README clearly explains the lab and links to screenshots + dashboard XML.

Troubleshooting:
- If you feel like you found â€œnothing,â€ thatâ€™s normal in baselining. The skill is knowing what you would detect and how youâ€™d operationalize it.

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Optional upgrades (make it feel like a real SOC lab)
steps.body:
Pick 1â€“3 upgrades (optional):

A) Generate realistic events:
- Attempt a few failed SSH logins (controlled).
- Run sudo commands.
- Restart services.
- Create a few user accounts.

B) Add a scheduled search + alert (even if you donâ€™t trigger it):
- Schedule the Auth Failures search to run every 5 minutes.
- Trigger if count > X.

C) Normalize fields:
- Add a field extraction for username or src_ip.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of the scheduled search setup.
- Notes on thresholds and false positives.

Validation:
- Dashboard becomes more â€œaliveâ€ and clearly SOC-relevant.

On your machine, clone your repo and navigate to the project folder.

Commands:
- `git clone https://github.com/GreyKeyStudios/CyberSecurity-Projects.git`
- `cd CyberSecurity-Projects/Threat-Intelligence`

Validation:
- You should see files like:
  - `README.md`
  - your Python script(s) (example: `ioc_enrichment.py` or similar)
  - output folder or sample report

Troubleshooting:
- If you get an auth error cloning, use GitHub Desktop or clone with SSH instead:
  - `git clone git@github.com:GreyKeyStudios/CyberSecurity-Projects.git`

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Create and activate a Python virtual environment
steps.body:
A venv keeps your project dependencies isolated.

Windows (PowerShell):
- `python -m venv venv`
- `venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1`

Windows (CMD):
- `python -m venv venv`
- `venv\Scripts\activate.bat`

Linux/macOS:
- `python3 -m venv venv`
- `source venv/bin/activate`

Validation:
- Your terminal should show `(venv)` at the start of the prompt.

Troubleshooting:
- If activation is blocked on Windows:
  - Run PowerShell as admin
  - `Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned`
  - Then try again

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Install dependencies (requests + dotenv recommended)
steps.body:
If your project already includes a requirements file, install from it.

Option A (recommended if requirements.txt exists):
- `pip install -r requirements.txt`

Option B (manual install):
- `pip install requests python-dotenv`

Optional but useful:
- `pip install rich`

Validation:
- Run: `pip freeze` and confirm you see `requests`.

Troubleshooting:
- If pip fails, upgrade it:
  - `python -m pip install --upgrade pip`

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Create API accounts and generate keys
steps.body:
This tool depends on free (or freemium) threat intel APIs.

Create accounts and keys:
1) VirusTotal
- Create a VirusTotal account
- Generate an API key

2) AbuseIPDB
- Create an account
- Generate an API key

3) AlienVault OTX
- Create an OTX account
- Generate an API key

Important:
- Free tiers are rate-limited. Thatâ€™s fine for this lab.

Deliverable:
- Save your keys in a safe place. Do NOT commit them to GitHub.

Validation:
- You have 3 keys copied into a secure notes file temporarily.

Troubleshooting:
- If VirusTotal API returns 403, your key may not be activated yet. Wait a few minutes and retry.

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Store API keys securely using a .env file
steps.body:
In `Threat-Intelligence/`, create a `.env` file.

Example `.env`:
```
VT_API_KEY=your_virustotal_key_here
ABUSEIPDB_API_KEY=your_abuseipdb_key_here
OTX_API_KEY=your_otx_key_here
```

Then create/update `.gitignore` so `.env` is never uploaded.

Add this line to `.gitignore`:
- `.env`

Validation:
- `.env` exists locally.
- `.gitignore` contains `.env`.

Troubleshooting:
- If you accidentally committed `.env`, remove it immediately and rotate keys.

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Confirm the script supports multiple IOC types (IP, domain, hash)
steps.body:
Your enrichment tool should accept at least:
- IP address (ex: 8.8.8.8)
- Domain (ex: example.com)
- Hash (MD5/SHA1/SHA256)

Typical input formats:
Option A (CLI argument):
- `python ioc_tool.py --ioc 8.8.8.8`

Option B (prompt input):
- `python ioc_tool.py`

If your script is missing input validation, add a basic IOC classifier:
- Regex for IPv4
- Simple domain check
- Hash length check (32, 40, 64)

Validation:
- Script runs without crashing.
- Script prints what IOC type it detected.

Troubleshooting:
- If the script always treats input as domain, your classifier logic needs adjustment.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Implement the VirusTotal lookup module (most important)
steps.body:
VirusTotal is usually the best â€œfirst stopâ€ IOC enrichment.

Common VT endpoints:
- IP: `https://www.virustotal.com/api/v3/ip_addresses/{ip}`
- Domain: `https://www.virustotal.com/api/v3/domains/{domain}`
- Hash: `https://www.virustotal.com/api/v3/files/{hash}`

Example requests usage:
- Header: `x-apikey: <VT_API_KEY>`

Validation:
- Script prints:
  - malicious/suspicious/harmless counts
  - reputation score (if available)
  - last analysis date

Troubleshooting:
- If you get 401: key is wrong.
- If you get 429: rate limit hit; wait 1â€“2 minutes.

Deliverable:
- Ensure VT output is saved in the final report.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Implement AbuseIPDB lookup for IP reputation scoring
steps.body:
AbuseIPDB is specifically strong for IP-based abuse history.

Endpoint:
- `https://api.abuseipdb.com/api/v2/check`

Example parameters:
- `ipAddress=<ip>`
- `maxAgeInDays=90`
- `verbose=true`

Header:
- `Key: <ABUSEIPDB_API_KEY>`
- `Accept: application/json`

Expected fields:
- abuseConfidenceScore
- totalReports
- countryCode
- isp

Validation:
- Output includes a confidence score and report count.

Troubleshooting:
- AbuseIPDB only supports IPs, not domains/hashes.
- If your script tries to call it on a domain, skip gracefully and note it.

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Implement OTX lookup for pulse intelligence
steps.body:
AlienVault OTX is useful because it provides context (pulses) and related IOCs.

OTX endpoints vary by IOC type. Common approach:
- Use the OTX Indicator API.

What to extract:
- pulses (campaigns)
- tags
- malware families
- references

Validation:
- Script outputs at least:
  - pulse count
  - top pulse name
  - tags

Troubleshooting:
- If OTX returns empty, that doesnâ€™t mean the IOC is safeâ€”document it as â€œno known pulses found.â€

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Normalize all results into one report format
steps.body:
SOC analysts want one clean report, not raw API dumps.

Recommended report format:
- IOC Summary section
- Risk rating (Low/Medium/High)
- VirusTotal results
- AbuseIPDB results
- OTX results
- Analyst notes

Example risk rating logic:
- High: VT malicious > 5 OR AbuseIPDB score > 50 OR OTX pulses > 3
- Medium: VT malicious 1â€“5 OR AbuseIPDB score 10â€“50
- Low: no detections + no reports

Validation:
- Report output is readable and consistent.

Deliverable:
- Save reports to:
  - `Threat-Intelligence/reports/`
Example:
- `Threat-Intelligence/reports/report_8.8.8.8.json`
- `Threat-Intelligence/reports/report_8.8.8.8.md`

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Add error handling and rate-limit resilience
steps.body:
Real SOC automation must handle failures.

Add handling for:
- HTTP 401 (bad key)
- HTTP 403 (blocked access)
- HTTP 429 (rate limit)
- request timeouts
- invalid IOC formats

Recommended practices:
- `timeout=10` in requests
- wrap API calls in try/except
- print meaningful errors

Validation:
- If you remove a key, script fails gracefully.
- If you query too fast, script explains rate limit.

Troubleshooting:
- If your script crashes with KeyError, your JSON parsing needs `.get()` defaults.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Add CLI arguments (makes it feel professional)
steps.body:
Add `argparse` so you can run it like a real tool.

Recommended usage:
- `python ioc_enrich.py --ioc 1.1.1.1 --format json`
- `python ioc_enrich.py --ioc example.com --format md`

Recommended flags:
- `--ioc`
- `--type` (optional override)
- `--format` (json/md/txt)
- `--outdir`
- `--verbose`

Validation:
- `python ioc_enrich.py -h` prints help output.

Deliverable:
- Add usage examples to README.

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Test with safe known IOCs (avoid illegal samples)
steps.body:
Do NOT test with real malware you downloaded.

Safe test IOCs:
- Public DNS IPs:
  - 1.1.1.1
  - 8.8.8.8
- Test domain:
  - example.com

If you want a â€œbadâ€ IOC for demo:
- Use a known public malicious IP from a threat intel blog or AbuseIPDB search results.

Validation:
- Your report generates successfully.
- API results appear for at least one IOC.

Troubleshooting:
- If everything comes back clean, thatâ€™s expected for safe test IOCs. Find a known flagged IP for a better demo.

steps.title: Step 14 â€” Capture portfolio evidence (screenshots + reports + README)
steps.body:
To make this job-ready, capture proof.

Evidence to save:
- Screenshot of successful run
- Screenshot of output report
- Sample report file

Recommended repo structure:
- `Threat-Intelligence/reports/`
- `Threat-Intelligence/screenshots/`

README should include:
- What the tool does
- Which APIs are supported
- Setup steps
- How to store API keys (.env)
- Example commands
- Sample output screenshot

Validation:
- Someone else can clone your repo, add keys, and run it successfully.

steps.title: Step 15 â€” Optional upgrades (adds real SOC credibility)
steps.body:
Pick 1â€“3 upgrades:

A) Add CSV batch mode
- Input a file of IOCs
- Output a combined CSV report

B) Add caching
- Save API results locally to avoid repeated API calls

C) Add IOC pivoting
- Extract related domains/ips from VT
- Enrich them automatically

D) Add a summary verdict
- "This IOC appears associated with botnet activity"

Deliverables:
- Add a `batch_reports/` folder
- Add new README section for batch mode

successCriteria: Tool successfully enriches IP/domain/hash IOCs using at least 2 APIs
API keys are loaded securely via .env and not committed to GitHub
Tool produces structured output report(s) saved in the repo
Script includes basic error handling and does not crash on invalid input
README provides setup + usage examples and a visitor can reproduce results

troubleshooting.issue: VirusTotal returns 401 Unauthorized
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm your VT key is correct in `.env`. Make sure your script is loading environment variables (python-dotenv). Print a debug message confirming the key exists (without printing the key itself).

troubleshooting.issue: VirusTotal returns 429 Too Many Requests
troubleshooting.fix: You hit the free-tier rate limit. Wait 60â€“120 seconds and retry. Add a delay (sleep) between API calls if running batch mode.

troubleshooting.issue: AbuseIPDB returns empty or missing fields
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm you are sending the correct headers: `Key:` and `Accept: application/json`. Also ensure you are passing `ipAddress=` in query params.

troubleshooting.issue: OTX returns no pulses
troubleshooting.fix: This is normal for many IOCs. Treat it as "no known pulses found" rather than "safe". Include that statement in your report.

troubleshooting.issue: Script crashes with KeyError when parsing JSON
troubleshooting.fix: Use `.get()` for nested dictionary fields. APIs often omit keys depending on the IOC.

troubleshooting.issue: My .env variables aren't loading
troubleshooting.fix: Make sure you call `load_dotenv()` early in your script. Confirm the `.env` file is in the same folder where you run the script.

firewall-setup.title: Firewall Setup (UFW Hardening Lab)
prereqs: Basic understanding of TCP/UDP ports
Basic Linux commands (cd, ls, sudo)
Understanding of inbound vs outbound traffic
firewall-setup.objective: Configure a Linux host firewall using UFW to enforce secure defaults, allow only required services, validate the rules using port scans, and document the results like a SOC analyst would for a hardening checklist.
deliverables: UFW configured with secure default rules
Documented firewall ruleset output (`ufw status verbose`)
Screenshots proving firewall rules applied
nmap scan evidence showing blocked vs allowed ports
README updates describing configuration and verification steps
Optional: a baseline hardening checklist saved in the repo

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Spin up a Linux VM and confirm network connectivity
steps.body:
This lab is easiest using Ubuntu (22.04+ recommended) inside VirtualBox, VMware, or a cloud VM.

Goal:
- You need a machine where you have sudo access.

Commands:
- `ip a`
- `ping -c 4 8.8.8.8`
- `ping -c 4 google.com`

Validation:
- `ping 8.8.8.8` confirms network connectivity.
- `ping google.com` confirms DNS resolution.

Troubleshooting:
- If DNS fails but IP ping works, check `/etc/resolv.conf`.
- If both fail, your VM network adapter may be misconfigured (NAT/bridged issue).

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing `ip a` and successful ping output.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Locate the project folder in the repo
steps.body:
Navigate to your CyberSecurity-Projects repo and open the firewall lab folder.

Commands:
- `cd ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/Firewall-Setup`
- `ls -la`

Validation:
- You should see a `README.md` and any supporting documentation files.

Troubleshooting:
- If the folder doesnâ€™t exist, you may not be in the repo directory.
- Use `pwd` to confirm where you are.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing the folder contents.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Install UFW (if not already installed)
steps.body:
Most Ubuntu systems already include UFW, but confirm.

Commands:
- `sudo ufw status`

If UFW is missing:
- `sudo apt update`
- `sudo apt install ufw -y`

Validation:
- Running `sudo ufw status` should show either inactive or active.

Troubleshooting:
- If apt fails, check internet access and run:
  - `sudo apt update --fix-missing`

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing UFW installed and status output.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Check current listening ports before enabling firewall
steps.body:
Before configuring firewall rules, identify what ports/services are running.

Commands:
- `sudo ss -tulnp`

Alternative:
- `sudo netstat -tulnp` (if installed)

Validation:
- You should see output listing listening ports.

SOC Mindset:
- If nothing is listening except maybe SSH, thatâ€™s good.
- If you see unexpected services (Apache, MySQL, etc.), document it.

Deliverable:
- Copy the output into a notes file or screenshot it.

Troubleshooting:
- If `ss` is not found:
  - `sudo apt install iproute2 -y`

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Set secure default firewall policies (deny inbound, allow outbound)
steps.body:
A secure baseline is:
- Deny all inbound connections
- Allow outbound connections

Commands:
- `sudo ufw default deny incoming`
- `sudo ufw default allow outgoing`

Validation:
- Run:
  - `sudo ufw status verbose`
- You should see the default policies listed.

Troubleshooting:
- If you see an error about IPv6, you may need to adjust `/etc/default/ufw`.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of `ufw status verbose` after applying defaults.

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Allow SSH (IMPORTANT if you are using remote access)
steps.body:
If you're SSHâ€™d into this machine and you enable UFW without allowing SSH, you will lock yourself out.

If SSH is needed:
- `sudo ufw allow OpenSSH`

Or allow a specific port:
- `sudo ufw allow 22/tcp`

Validation:
- `sudo ufw status numbered`
- You should see an ALLOW rule for SSH.

Troubleshooting:
- If you donâ€™t know if SSH is installed:
  - `sudo systemctl status ssh`

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing SSH allowed.

If you're using local VM only:
- You can skip this step, but itâ€™s still good practice.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Enable UFW and confirm it is active
steps.body:
Now activate the firewall.

Command:
- `sudo ufw enable`

Then check status:
- `sudo ufw status verbose`

Validation:
- Output should say: `Status: active`

Troubleshooting:
- If you get warnings about existing rules, review them using:
  - `sudo ufw status numbered`

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing UFW is active.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Add a rule for a real service (example: allow HTTP/HTTPS)
steps.body:
This step demonstrates real-world firewall rule creation.

If you want to simulate a web server:
- `sudo ufw allow 80/tcp`
- `sudo ufw allow 443/tcp`

Validation:
- `sudo ufw status numbered`
- You should see rules allowing 80 and 443.

SOC Note:
- In a real environment, only allow ports required for business operations.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing the allowed ports.

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Block a port explicitly (deny rule example)
steps.body:
Even though inbound is denied by default, itâ€™s useful to practice explicit deny rules.

Example: deny Telnet
- `sudo ufw deny 23/tcp`

Validation:
- `sudo ufw status numbered`

SOC Note:
- Explicit denies are often used for documentation clarity.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing deny rule exists.

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Test firewall behavior locally with netcat
steps.body:
Use netcat to simulate a service and test if firewall rules allow/block it.

Start a test listener on port 8080:
- `nc -lvp 8080`

In a second terminal, test it:
- `nc 127.0.0.1 8080`

Important:
- UFW usually does NOT block loopback traffic by default.
- Real validation requires scanning from another host.

Deliverable:
- Note this limitation in README.

Troubleshooting:
- If `nc` is missing:
  - `sudo apt install netcat-openbsd -y`

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Validate firewall rules using nmap from another machine
steps.body:
This is the most important validation step.

You need another machine (Kali VM, Windows host, or another Linux VM).

Find your target IP:
- `ip a`

From attacker/scanner machine run:
- `nmap -sS -Pn <target-ip>`

Optional full port scan:
- `nmap -p- -T4 -Pn <target-ip>`

Validation:
- Allowed ports (SSH/80/443) should show as open.
- Everything else should show as filtered/closed.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of the nmap output.

Troubleshooting:
- If ALL ports show closed, the VM may not be reachable (wrong IP or NAT isolation).
- If ports show open unexpectedly, check services running with:
  - `sudo ss -tulnp`

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Enable logging and review firewall log output
steps.body:
Logging is crucial for security monitoring.

Enable logging:
- `sudo ufw logging on`

Check log level:
- `sudo ufw status verbose`

View firewall logs:
- `sudo tail -n 50 /var/log/ufw.log`

Validation:
- You should see logged blocked/allowed events.

SOC Note:
- These logs can later be shipped into Splunk/SIEM.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of `/var/log/ufw.log` output.

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Export firewall configuration evidence for documentation
steps.body:
Capture your final configuration output.

Commands:
- `sudo ufw status verbose > ufw_status_verbose.txt`
- `sudo ufw status numbered > ufw_status_numbered.txt`

Move these into your repo folder:
- `mv ufw_status_verbose.txt Firewall-Setup/`
- `mv ufw_status_numbered.txt Firewall-Setup/`

Validation:
- Files appear inside the Firewall-Setup folder.

Deliverable:
- Two evidence files saved in the project folder.

steps.title: Step 14 â€” Document the lab like a real security hardening ticket
steps.body:
Update your README to include:

Sections to include:
- Overview: what UFW is
- Threat model: why firewalls matter
- Default policy config
- Rules added (SSH, HTTP, etc.)
- Logging configuration
- Validation results (nmap evidence)
- Screenshots list
- Lessons learned

Recommended screenshot folder:
- `Firewall-Setup/screenshots/`

Recommended evidence folder:
- `Firewall-Setup/evidence/`

Validation:
- README includes commands and verification steps.
- A beginner could repeat the lab using your documentation.

steps.title: Step 15 â€” Optional upgrade: add a custom application profile
steps.body:
UFW supports application profiles stored in `/etc/ufw/applications.d/`.

View existing profiles:
- `sudo ufw app list`

Example: allow a profile
- `sudo ufw allow 'OpenSSH'`

If you want to create your own profile:
- Create a new file in `/etc/ufw/applications.d/`
- Define ports and protocols

Validation:
- `sudo ufw app list` shows your custom profile.

Deliverable:
- Mention custom profile setup in README.

steps.title: Step 16 â€” Optional upgrade: simulate brute force attempts and observe logs
steps.body:
To simulate repeated connection attempts, run an nmap scan or repeated SSH attempts from another machine.

Example:
- `nmap -sS -T4 -Pn <target-ip>`

Then watch logs:
- `sudo tail -f /var/log/ufw.log`

Validation:
- Log entries appear in real time.

SOC Note:
- This is a basic simulation of hostile recon.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing live log monitoring.

successCriteria: UFW is enabled with default deny incoming / allow outgoing policy
Only required ports are allowed (example: SSH/80/443)
Firewall logging is enabled and /var/log/ufw.log shows traffic events
nmap scan confirms blocked vs allowed ports
README includes commands, validation output, and troubleshooting notes
Evidence files and screenshots are stored in the repo for portfolio proof

troubleshooting.issue: I enabled UFW and lost SSH access
troubleshooting.fix: If you have console access, disable firewall temporarily: `sudo ufw disable`, then add `sudo ufw allow OpenSSH` and re-enable. If you are locked out remotely with no console, you may need to rebuild the VM.

troubleshooting.issue: nmap shows all ports closed even though SSH should be open
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm SSH service is running: `sudo systemctl status ssh`. Confirm VM IP is correct. Confirm VM networking mode allows inbound connections (bridged recommended).

troubleshooting.issue: UFW logging is enabled but ufw.log is empty
troubleshooting.fix: Generate traffic by scanning the VM from another host. Use `nmap -Pn <ip>` then re-check `sudo tail -n 50 /var/log/ufw.log`.

troubleshooting.issue: ufw enable fails with IPv6 warnings
troubleshooting.fix: Edit `/etc/default/ufw` and set `IPV6=yes` or `no` depending on your environment, then reload UFW.

troubleshooting.issue: UFW rules don't seem to work
troubleshooting.fix: Run `sudo ufw status numbered` to confirm rules exist. Also check `sudo iptables -L -n` to confirm UFW is applying rules under the hood.

soc-casefiles.title: SOC Casefiles
prereqs: Basic understanding of phishing, malware, and suspicious logins
Comfortable reading technical text
Basic understanding of IP addresses, domains, and hashes
Willingness to document your thought process clearly
soc-casefiles.objective: Build a reusable SOC-style investigation library using realistic casefile writeups and playbooks. This project is designed to train incident response thinking, documentation, IOC extraction, and analyst communication.
deliverables: At least 3 completed SOC casefiles written in a consistent format
At least 3 operational playbooks written like SOC runbooks
Evidence screenshots and IOC lists in each casefile
A repeatable template process so new casefiles can be added later
A portfolio-ready SOC documentation folder that demonstrates real analyst workflow

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Understand what this project is (and why it matters)
steps.body:
SOC-Casefiles is not a traditional technical lab.

It is a SOC analyst training project designed to prove you can:
- read an incident scenario
- extract key indicators
- validate indicators using threat intel sources
- document findings clearly
- write actionable remediation steps
- communicate like a real SOC analyst

This project is extremely valuable for interviews because most beginner portfolios show tools â€” but not analyst thinking.

Validation:
- You should be able to explain (out loud) what a casefile is.
- You should understand that your main deliverable is documentation.

Deliverable:
- None yet (this is a mindset step).

Troubleshooting:
- If you feel like "this isn't real cybersecurity," you are wrong. Documentation is a core SOC skill.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Open the SOC-Casefiles folder and inspect the structure
steps.body:
Navigate to the project folder in your repo.

If you are in the repo root:

Linux/macOS:
```bash
cd SOC-Casefiles
ls
```

Windows PowerShell:
```powershell
cd SOC-Casefiles
dir
```

You should see subfolders for casefiles and playbooks (folder names may vary depending on your repo).

What you're looking for:
- Casefile markdown documents
- Playbook markdown documents
- Any images/screenshots folder

Validation:
- You can locate existing casefiles and playbooks.

Deliverable:
- Identify and write down the file paths of:
  - where casefiles live
  - where playbooks live

Troubleshooting:
- If the folder is empty or doesn't match expectations, confirm you're in the correct repo and branch.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Pick a casefile to study like an analyst
steps.body:
Choose one casefile to review.

Start with the most complete one.

Open it in VS Code or another Markdown editor.

What you should learn from the casefile:
- how the incident was introduced
- what evidence was available
- what indicators were extracted
- how the analysis was performed
- what remediation was recommended

Your goal is to identify the "structure" so you can reuse it.

Validation:
- You can summarize the casefile in 2 sentences.

Deliverable:
- Create a note (in your own scratchpad) listing the sections the casefile uses (ex: Summary, IOCs, Timeline, Findings, Recommendations).

Troubleshooting:
- If the casefile feels confusing, skip analysis details and focus on headings/sections first.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Extract IOCs (Indicators of Compromise) from the casefile
steps.body:
In every casefile, identify all IOCs.

Common IOC types:
- IP addresses
- domains
- URLs
- file hashes (MD5/SHA1/SHA256)
- suspicious email sender addresses
- file names
- registry keys
- user accounts

Make a list of all IOCs.

Pro tip: Always defang URLs when documenting them publicly.

Defanging examples:
- http://example.com â†’ hxxp://example[.]com
- bad.domain.com â†’ bad[.]domain[.]com

Validation:
- You have a clean IOC list.

Deliverable:
- Create an IOC section inside the casefile if one does not exist.

Troubleshooting:
- If you don't see IOCs, treat names, file paths, and user accounts as indicators.
- Even "suspicious process name" counts as an IOC in many investigations.

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Validate IOCs using threat intelligence sources
steps.body:
Every SOC casefile should show that you validated indicators.

Use at least 2â€“3 sources per IOC type.

Recommended sources:
- VirusTotal (hashes/domains/URLs/IPs)
- AbuseIPDB (IPs)
- AlienVault OTX (IPs/domains)
- urlscan.io (URLs/domains)
- Hybrid Analysis (hashes)
- ANY.RUN (dynamic analysis)

Example workflow:
1. Check suspicious IP in AbuseIPDB
2. Check same IP in VirusTotal
3. Search domain on urlscan.io

Record:
- reputation score
- tags (phishing, malware, botnet)
- detection counts
- first seen / last seen dates

Validation:
- You can answer: "Is this IOC known bad?"

Deliverable:
- Add a "Threat Intel Findings" section with bullet notes.

Troubleshooting:
- If VirusTotal says 0 detections, it does NOT mean safe. Note that it is "unknown" or "low confidence."

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Write the investigation timeline like a real SOC ticket
steps.body:
A strong casefile includes a timeline.

Even if the incident is fictional, write it like an investigation log.

Timeline format example:
- 09:12 AM â€” User reports suspicious email
- 09:20 AM â€” URL extracted and checked in VirusTotal
- 09:35 AM â€” IOC confirmed malicious, blocked domain
- 10:05 AM â€” User password reset initiated

Include:
- timestamps (even approximate)
- action taken
- result

Validation:
- Timeline reads like a sequence of SOC actions.

Deliverable:
- Add a "Timeline" section to the casefile.

Troubleshooting:
- If you don't know exact times, use "T+0, T+15 min, T+45 min" style instead.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Document the technical analysis (how you reached conclusions)
steps.body:
This is the section that makes your portfolio impressive.

Write what you actually did:
- what you checked
- what evidence you found
- why you concluded it was malicious or suspicious

Example analysis language:
"The sender domain was newly registered and had no reputation history. URLScan results showed multiple redirects to a credential harvesting page. VirusTotal flagged the final URL as phishing. Based on the combined evidence, the email was classified as credential phishing."

Use SOC-style confidence labels:
- High confidence malicious
- Medium confidence suspicious
- Low confidence / informational

Validation:
- Someone reading the casefile understands your reasoning.

Deliverable:
- Add a "Findings" section that contains:
  - What happened
  - Evidence collected
  - IOC validation
  - Conclusion

Troubleshooting:
- If you feel like you're repeating yourself, that's normal. SOC documentation is repetitive by design.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Add remediation and response recommendations
steps.body:
A SOC analyst must propose remediation.

Include:
- immediate containment steps
- short-term remediation
- long-term preventive improvements

Examples:
Immediate:
- block domain in DNS filtering
- reset password for affected account
- isolate host from network

Preventive:
- enforce MFA
- add mail rule for spoofed sender
- improve phishing training

Validation:
- Your remediation steps are actionable.

Deliverable:
- Add a "Recommended Actions" section.

Troubleshooting:
- If you don't know what to recommend, use NIST incident response lifecycle as a guide (Containment, Eradication, Recovery).

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Add screenshots and evidence artifacts (portfolio proof)
steps.body:
A strong casefile should contain proof.

Add screenshots such as:
- VirusTotal detection page
- AbuseIPDB reputation score
- urlscan.io results
- email headers
- Splunk search output (if applicable)
- Wireshark packet view (if applicable)

Store screenshots inside the SOC-Casefiles folder.

Recommended structure:
SOC-Casefiles/
  Casefiles/
    Casefile-001.md
  Evidence/
    casefile-001/
      vt_result.png
      abuseipdb.png

In Markdown, reference images like:
```md
![VirusTotal Results](../Evidence/casefile-001/vt_result.png)
```

Validation:
- Images render correctly in GitHub preview.

Deliverable:
- Add at least 2 screenshots per casefile.

Troubleshooting:
- If images don't render on GitHub, check relative paths and case sensitivity.

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Review playbooks and connect them to casefiles
steps.body:
Playbooks are operational guides.

Casefiles show investigations.

A strong SOC portfolio links them together.

For example:
- A phishing casefile should link to the Phishing Triage playbook.
- A malware casefile should link to a Malware Triage playbook.

In the casefile, add a line like:
"Relevant playbook: Playbooks/Phishing-Triage.md"

Validation:
- Casefile references the correct playbook.

Deliverable:
- Add at least one playbook reference per casefile.

Troubleshooting:
- If playbooks are incomplete, create a minimal version with 6â€“10 steps. Better minimal than missing.

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Create a new casefile using the same template (repeatability)
steps.body:
Now create your own new casefile.

Pick a scenario:
- credential phishing
- suspicious login from foreign IP
- ransomware detection
- suspicious PowerShell activity
- malicious attachment

Recommended casefile structure:
1. Executive Summary
2. Incident Description
3. Indicators of Compromise
4. Evidence Collected
5. Timeline
6. Findings / Analysis
7. Response Actions
8. Recommendations
9. Lessons Learned

Write it like you are documenting a real ticket.

Validation:
- Casefile has all sections.
- Casefile includes IOCs.
- Casefile includes threat intel checks.

Deliverable:
- Add at least one original casefile.

Troubleshooting:
- If you don't know what incident to use, use one of your Tickets app scenarios as the source story.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Final polish: make it interview-ready
steps.body:
This is the final step that turns "notes" into a portfolio.

Checklist:
- spelling and formatting cleaned up
- consistent headings across casefiles
- IOCs defanged
- screenshots included
- timeline included
- clear conclusion (malicious/suspicious/benign)
- remediation included
- playbook referenced

Add a "Lessons Learned" section to show maturity.

Validation:
- A recruiter could open any casefile and understand it.

Deliverable:
- Final review pass on all casefiles.

Troubleshooting:
- If the writing feels too long, tighten your Executive Summary. Keep technical detail in Findings.

successCriteria: At least 3 casefiles exist with consistent formatting and clear conclusions
Each casefile includes an IOC list with threat intel validation
Each casefile includes at least 2 evidence screenshots
Each casefile includes remediation recommendations
Playbooks exist and are referenced from relevant casefiles
A new casefile can be created from scratch using the same workflow

troubleshooting.issue: I don't know what to write in the Findings section.
troubleshooting.fix: Write exactly what you checked and what the result was. Example: "Checked IP in AbuseIPDB. Score was 95/100. Multiple reports tagged as brute force. Classified as malicious."

troubleshooting.issue: The casefile feels fake because I don't have real logs.
troubleshooting.fix: Casefiles can be based on simulated tickets, public incident reports, or sandbox results. SOC documentation skill is still valid and valuable.

troubleshooting.issue: My casefile has no IOCs.
troubleshooting.fix: Extract anything measurable: domains, file names, user accounts, email headers, suspicious process names, or command line arguments.

troubleshooting.issue: My screenshots don't show enough proof.
troubleshooting.fix: Add screenshots of your threat intel results and highlight the key lines (detections, tags, reputation scores).

troubleshooting.issue: My writing is too long.
troubleshooting.fix: Keep the Executive Summary short. Move details into Findings and Timeline. SOC reports are structured so readers can skim.

ids-setup.title: IDS Setup (Suricata / Snort Detection Lab)
prereqs: Basic Linux administration (systemctl, apt, editing config files)
Understanding of TCP/IP, ports, and protocols
Basic familiarity with packet capture concepts
Comfort reading logs
ids-setup.objective: Deploy an Intrusion Detection System (IDS) on a Linux host using Suricata (or Snort), configure it to monitor traffic, generate alerts from test attacks, and validate detection by analyzing alert logs and rule hits like a SOC analyst.
deliverables: Suricata installed and running as a service
Configured Suricata interface monitoring (eth0 or correct NIC)
Alerts generated from simulated attacks (nmap scan, HTTP requests, etc.)
Saved evidence: suricata logs (`fast.log`, `eve.json`)
Screenshots of alert output and service status
README documentation showing setup, validation, and troubleshooting steps
Optional: custom IDS rule written and tested

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Create your IDS VM and confirm network connectivity
steps.body:
Spin up a Linux VM (Ubuntu Server recommended). The IDS works best when the VM has real network access.

Recommended VM setup:
- 2 CPU cores
- 4GB RAM
- 20GB storage
- Bridged adapter if possible (so it sees real LAN traffic)

Commands:
- `ip a`
- `ping -c 4 8.8.8.8`
- `ping -c 4 google.com`

Validation:
- You can ping external IPs and resolve DNS.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing IP address + successful ping.

Troubleshooting:
- If ping fails, check VM network mode (NAT vs bridged).
- If DNS fails, verify `/etc/resolv.conf`.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Navigate into the IDS project folder
steps.body:
Open the project directory in your CyberSecurity-Projects repo.

Commands:
- `cd ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/IDS_Setup`
- `ls -la`

Validation:
- You should see a README and/or supporting files.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of folder contents.

SOC Note:
- This lab folder is where your screenshots, exported logs, and rule files will live.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Update system packages and install dependencies
steps.body:
Before installing Suricata, update packages and install utilities.

Commands:
- `sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y`
- `sudo apt install -y curl wget jq tcpdump net-tools unzip`

Optional:
- Install Wireshark CLI tools:
  - `sudo apt install -y tshark`

Validation:
- `tcpdump --version` returns output.
- `jq --version` returns output.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing successful installs.

Troubleshooting:
- If apt fails, rerun `sudo apt update` and check network connectivity.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Install Suricata
steps.body:
Install Suricata from Ubuntu repositories.

Commands:
- `sudo apt install -y suricata`

Confirm install:
- `suricata --build-info`

Validation:
- Suricata version output appears.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of `suricata --build-info`.

SOC Note:
- Suricata is a modern IDS/IPS engine that outputs JSON logs (eve.json), making it SIEM-friendly.

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Identify the correct network interface to monitor
steps.body:
Suricata must listen on the correct NIC.

Commands:
- `ip link show`
- `ip a`

Common interface names:
- `eth0`
- `ens33`
- `enp0s3`

Validation:
- Identify which interface has your real IP.

Deliverable:
- Write down your interface name (example: `ens33`).

Troubleshooting:
- If you see multiple interfaces, pick the one with your assigned IP (not lo/loopback).

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Configure Suricata to monitor your interface
steps.body:
Suricata configuration file:
- `/etc/suricata/suricata.yaml`

First, back it up:
- `sudo cp /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml.bak`

Edit the file:
- `sudo nano /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml`

Look for the `af-packet:` section and ensure your interface is listed.
Example:
```
af-packet:
  - interface: ens33
```

Some installs use `pcap:` mode instead.

Validation:
- Configuration includes your correct interface.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of the relevant config section.

Troubleshooting:
- If Suricata fails to start later, restore backup:
  - `sudo cp /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml.bak /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml`

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Download and update Suricata rules
steps.body:
Suricata needs rules to detect malicious patterns.

Update rules using suricata-update:
- `sudo suricata-update`

Confirm rules exist:
- `ls -la /var/lib/suricata/rules/`

The main rule file is usually:
- `/var/lib/suricata/rules/suricata.rules`

Validation:
- suricata-update finishes without errors.
- Rule files exist in `/var/lib/suricata/rules/`.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing rules downloaded.

Troubleshooting:
- If update fails, check DNS/internet connectivity.
- If rules directory is empty, rerun `sudo suricata-update`.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Run Suricata in test mode (validate configuration)
steps.body:
Before enabling Suricata as a service, validate the config.

Command:
- `sudo suricata -T -c /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml -v`

Validation:
- Output should include: `Configuration provided was successfully loaded.`

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of successful test output.

Troubleshooting:
- If you see YAML parsing errors, re-check indentation.
- Restore from backup if needed.

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Start and enable Suricata service
steps.body:
Now start Suricata as a service.

Commands:
- `sudo systemctl start suricata`
- `sudo systemctl enable suricata`

Check status:
- `sudo systemctl status suricata --no-pager`

Validation:
- Service shows `active (running)`.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing active service.

Troubleshooting:
- If it fails, check logs:
  - `sudo journalctl -u suricata -n 50 --no-pager`

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Locate Suricata output logs (fast.log and eve.json)
steps.body:
Suricata logs are usually stored here:
- `/var/log/suricata/`

Check files:
- `ls -la /var/log/suricata/`

Common files:
- `fast.log` (human readable alerts)
- `eve.json` (structured JSON event output)
- `stats.log`

View alerts:
- `sudo tail -n 50 /var/log/suricata/fast.log`

View JSON events:
- `sudo tail -n 5 /var/log/suricata/eve.json | jq .`

Validation:
- Logs exist and are updating.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing files in /var/log/suricata.

Troubleshooting:
- If logs are empty, generate traffic and ensure Suricata is running.

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Generate test traffic (safe recon simulation)
steps.body:
To trigger alerts, generate network activity.

From another machine (Kali/Windows):
- `nmap -sS -Pn <IDS-IP>`

From IDS machine itself:
- `curl http://example.com`
- `ping -c 5 1.1.1.1`

Optional: aggressive scan (still safe):
- `nmap -A -T4 -Pn <IDS-IP>`

Validation:
- Alerts appear in fast.log.

Check:
- `sudo tail -n 100 /var/log/suricata/fast.log`

Deliverable:
- Screenshot showing scan output + Suricata alerts.

SOC Note:
- Recon scans are one of the most common "first indicators" of intrusion attempts.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Analyze Suricata alerts like a SOC analyst
steps.body:
Your job is not just to "see alerts" but to interpret them.

Check recent alerts:
- `sudo tail -n 50 /var/log/suricata/fast.log`

Extract alert events from eve.json:
- `sudo cat /var/log/suricata/eve.json | jq 'select(.event_type=="alert")' | head -n 20`

Look for:
- signature name
- severity
- source/destination IP
- ports

Validation:
- You can identify at least 2 alerts and explain what triggered them.

Deliverable:
- Write 2â€“3 bullet analysis notes into README or a notes file (example: `IDS_Setup/alert-analysis.md`).

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Create and test a custom Suricata rule
steps.body:
Writing a rule is the most valuable skill-building part of this lab.

Create a custom rule file:
- `sudo nano /etc/suricata/rules/local.rules`

Example rule (detect a test keyword):
```
alert http any any -> any any (msg:"SOC OS TEST RULE - suspicious keyword"; content:"eviltest"; http_uri; sid:9999999; rev:1;)
```

Now ensure local.rules is referenced in suricata.yaml.
Look for:
- `rule-files:`

Add or confirm:
- `- local.rules`

Test config:
- `sudo suricata -T -c /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml -v`

Restart Suricata:
- `sudo systemctl restart suricata`

Trigger the rule:
- `curl "http://<IDS-IP>/eviltest"`

Validation:
- Your custom alert appears in fast.log.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of your local.rules file + alert output.

Troubleshooting:
- If no alert triggers, ensure rule is loaded and Suricata restarted.

steps.title: Step 14 â€” Export logs and evidence into the repo folder
steps.body:
Copy Suricata evidence into your project folder so the lab is portable.

Recommended folder structure:
- `IDS_Setup/evidence/`
- `IDS_Setup/screenshots/`

Commands:
- `mkdir -p ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/IDS_Setup/evidence`
- `sudo cp /var/log/suricata/fast.log ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/IDS_Setup/evidence/fast.log`
- `sudo cp /var/log/suricata/eve.json ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/IDS_Setup/evidence/eve.json`

Fix permissions:
- `sudo chown -R $USER:$USER ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/IDS_Setup/evidence`

Validation:
- Evidence files exist in repo folder.

Deliverable:
- `IDS_Setup/evidence/fast.log`
- `IDS_Setup/evidence/eve.json`

steps.title: Step 15 â€” Document the lab with validation and SOC-style findings
steps.body:
Update README.md with:

Recommended sections:
- What is an IDS?
- Why Suricata matters
- Setup steps (install + config)
- How rules were updated
- Test attack results (nmap scans)
- Custom rule test
- Evidence folder contents
- Lessons learned

Include a short SOC-style summary:
- "Observed recon attempt" (nmap)
- "Alert severity" and signature
- "Recommended action" (block at firewall, tune rule, whitelist internal scan)

Validation:
- A reader can reproduce your IDS setup from the README.

Deliverable:
- Updated README.md with commands + evidence references.

steps.title: Step 16 â€” Optional upgrade: forward Suricata logs into Splunk or SIEM
steps.body:
This is optional but makes the lab much more realistic.

If you already have Splunk or syslog forwarding:
- Use rsyslog or file monitoring to ship eve.json.

Example (basic approach):
- Configure rsyslog to forward /var/log/suricata/fast.log.

Validation:
- Alerts appear inside your SIEM.

Deliverable:
- Add a section in README describing the log forwarding approach.

SOC Note:
- In real SOC environments, Suricata is rarely read locally. It's forwarded to Splunk/Elastic/Sentinel.

successCriteria: Suricata is installed and running as an active service
Suricata rules are downloaded and updated successfully
fast.log and eve.json exist and contain IDS events
At least one alert is generated from a simulated recon scan
A custom Suricata rule is created and successfully triggered
Evidence logs are exported into the IDS_Setup folder
README includes full commands, validation steps, and troubleshooting guidance

troubleshooting.issue: Suricata service fails to start
troubleshooting.fix: Run `sudo journalctl -u suricata -n 100 --no-pager` to view errors. Then validate config with `sudo suricata -T -c /etc/suricata/suricata.yaml -v`. Most failures are caused by YAML indentation or invalid interface name.

troubleshooting.issue: No alerts appear in fast.log
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm Suricata is running (`sudo systemctl status suricata`). Generate traffic using `nmap -Pn <IDS-IP>` from another machine. Check if the correct interface is configured in suricata.yaml.

troubleshooting.issue: suricata-update fails or downloads no rules
troubleshooting.fix: Check internet/DNS. Run `ping -c 4 8.8.8.8` and `ping -c 4 google.com`. Retry with `sudo suricata-update`.

troubleshooting.issue: My custom rule does not trigger
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm local.rules is listed under `rule-files:` in suricata.yaml. Restart Suricata after changes. Run `sudo suricata -T` to confirm the rule loads. Verify your rule SID is unique.

troubleshooting.issue: eve.json output is hard to read
troubleshooting.fix: Use jq: `sudo tail -n 20 /var/log/suricata/eve.json | jq .` or filter alerts only: `sudo cat eve.json | jq 'select(.event_type=="alert")'`.
