malware-analysis.title: Malware Analysis (Triage Lab: Static + Dynamic)
tools: Isolated Malware VM (Windows recommended) OR Linux analysis VM
Any.Run (optional cloud sandbox) OR REMnux/FLARE VM (optional)
prereqs: Comfort with VM snapshots and isolated networks
Basic understanding of Windows processes, persistence, and networking
Familiarity with hashing and IOCs
Know what NOT to do (never execute unknown malware on a host machine)
malware-analysis.objective: Perform safe malware triage using a controlled environment: capture hashes, extract strings and metadata, observe behavior in a sandbox/VM, collect indicators of compromise (IOCs), and write a SOC-ready report with confidence levels and recommended actions.
deliverables: A safe analysis environment (VM) with snapshots and no direct access to production networks
Hash set (MD5/SHA1/SHA256) of the sample
Static triage notes (strings, PE metadata if applicable, embedded URLs/domains)
Dynamic observation notes (processes, persistence attempts, network connections)
Collected IOCs (domains, IPs, file paths, mutexes, registry keys, scheduled tasks, user-agent, etc.)
Evidence package (screenshots + exported logs/captures)
Final SOC-style malware triage report (Markdown/PDF)

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Create an isolated analysis environment (no regrets setup)
steps.body:
Rule #1: Never analyze unknown malware on your daily machine.

Create a dedicated Malware Analysis VM.
Recommended: Windows 10/11 VM (for typical malware behavior) + optional Linux analysis VM.

Isolation checklist:
- Use a hypervisor that supports snapshots (VirtualBox/VMware).
- Disable shared folders / clipboard sharing if possible.
- Use Host-only network or NAT with strict outbound control (preferred: host-only + simulated internet tools).
- Take a clean snapshot named: `CLEAN_BASELINE`.

Validation:
- You can revert to snapshot instantly.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of VM settings (network mode) + snapshot list.

Troubleshooting:
- If you need internet for tooling downloads, do that first, then snapshot, then isolate.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Create the project evidence folders in the repo
steps.body:
In your CyberSecurity-Projects repo, create a consistent evidence structure.

Commands:
- `cd ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/Malware-Analysis`
- `mkdir -p evidence/screenshots evidence/logs evidence/pcaps evidence/notes evidence/iocs`

Suggested files:
- `analysis-notes.md`
- `ioc-list.md`
- `malware-triage-report.md`

Validation:
- `ls -R evidence` shows the folders.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of folder structure.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Acquire a SAFE sample (or use a known benign test file)
steps.body:
For a universal walkthrough, this lab supports two paths:

Path A (recommended for practice): Use a known-safe test file (EICAR) to practice workflows.
- EICAR is NOT malware, but it exercises AV detection and handling procedures.

Path B (advanced): Use an intentionally vulnerable lab sample from a trusted training source.
- Only do this if you understand the risk.
- Do not use random malware from the internet.

Validation:
- You can explain exactly where your sample came from.

Deliverable:
- `evidence/notes/sample-source.md` describing the source and why itâ€™s safe/trusted.

Important:
- Do NOT paste or distribute real malware binaries inside public repos.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Compute file hashes and capture file metadata
steps.body:
Hashing is your anchor: it lets you correlate findings safely.

On Windows:
- `certutil -hashfile <sample> SHA256`
- `certutil -hashfile <sample> MD5`

On Linux:
- `sha256sum <sample>`
- `md5sum <sample>`

Record:
- SHA256, SHA1, MD5
- Filename, size, timestamps

Validation:
- Hashes are stored in your notes.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/notes/hashes.txt`
- Screenshot showing hash output.

Troubleshooting:
- If you canâ€™t access the file, confirm permissions and that you copied it into the VM correctly.

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Run a â€œhash-onlyâ€ reputation lookup (no uploads)
steps.body:
Use VirusTotal (or similar) responsibly: do a hash lookup first.

Rules:
- Prefer hash lookup only.
- Uploading samples can leak data and may violate policies.

What to capture:
- Detection ratio (e.g., 12/70)
- First seen / last seen
- Known names/family hints
- Reported behaviors (high-level)

Validation:
- You can cite the reputation summary without uploading the binary.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot or notes in `analysis-notes.md` under â€œReputation Checkâ€.

Troubleshooting:
- If no results, that may indicate a new sample OR a benign fileâ€”donâ€™t over-interpret.

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Static triage: strings + quick indicator harvesting
steps.body:
Goal: pull out obvious IOCs without executing anything.

On Linux (best for strings):
- `strings -n 6 <sample> | tee evidence/logs/strings.txt`

Optional (better): FLOSS (extracts obfuscated strings):
- `floss <sample> | tee evidence/logs/floss.txt`

Look for:
- URLs, domains, IPs
- suspicious file paths
- registry keys
- user-agent strings
- commands (powershell/cmd)

Quick filtering examples:
- `grep -Eo '(https?://[^ ]+)' evidence/logs/strings.txt | sort -u`
- `grep -Eo '([0-9]{1,3}\.){3}[0-9]{1,3}' evidence/logs/strings.txt | sort -u`

Validation:
- You extracted at least 5 candidate indicators.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/logs/strings.txt` (or floss output)
- `evidence/iocs/iocs-static.txt`

Troubleshooting:
- If strings output is empty, the file may be packed or not a typical binaryâ€”document that.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Identify file type and (optional) PE metadata
steps.body:
Determine what youâ€™re looking at: PE EXE/DLL, script, document macro, etc.

Linux:
- `file <sample>`

If itâ€™s a Windows PE file and you have tools:
- Extract PE metadata (imports, sections, compile time) using a PE viewer.

What to capture:
- File type
- Suspected packer/obfuscation
- Notable imports (networking, process injection hints)

Validation:
- Your notes clearly state file type and any suspicious metadata.

Deliverable:
- Section in `analysis-notes.md`: â€œStatic Metadataâ€.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Prepare dynamic analysis (instrumentation before execution)
steps.body:
If you plan to execute, instrument first.

Windows tooling (recommended):
- Procmon (Process Monitor)
- Process Explorer
- Autoruns

Network capture:
- Start Wireshark capture on the VM NIC.
- Save to `evidence/pcaps/dynamic-run-1.pcapng`

Baseline snapshot:
- Revert to `CLEAN_BASELINE`
- Take a second snapshot: `PRE_EXECUTION`

Validation:
- Procmon is ready, Wireshark capture running, snapshot taken.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot: Procmon filters open + Wireshark capturing.

Troubleshooting:
- If Wireshark sees nothing, confirm correct interface inside VM.

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Execute in a controlled way and observe behavior
steps.body:
Only proceed if youâ€™re confident youâ€™re in an isolated environment.

Execution plan:
- Start Procmon capture.
- Execute sample.
- Observe 2â€“5 minutes.
- Stop Procmon capture and save PML (or export CSV if you prefer).

What to watch:
- New processes spawned (cmd/powershell)
- Writes to AppData/Temp/System32
- Registry persistence keys
- Scheduled tasks
- Network connections and DNS requests

Validation:
- You can list:
  - process tree observed
  - file writes (top 3)
  - persistence attempt (if any)
  - network indicators (domains/IPs)

Deliverables:
- `evidence/screenshots/` (process tree + notable procmon events)
- `evidence/logs/procmon-run-1.pml` (or exported CSV)
- `evidence/pcaps/dynamic-run-1.pcapng`

Troubleshooting:
- If nothing happens, the sample may be sandbox-aware or requires arguments/admin. Document that and stop.

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Extract IOCs from dynamic artifacts
steps.body:
From Procmon and Wireshark, extract high-confidence indicators.

Wireshark tips:
- Filter DNS: `dns`
- Filter HTTP: `http`
- Filter TLS SNI (if present): `tls.handshake.extensions_server_name`

IOC categories:
- Domains / IPs
- URLs
- File paths
- Registry keys
- Scheduled task names
- Mutex names
- User-Agent

Validation:
- Your IOC list is clean (deduped), categorized, and tagged as static/dynamic.

Deliverable:
- `evidence/iocs/ioc-list.md` with sections:
  - High confidence
  - Medium confidence
  - Needs verification

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Optional: YARA rule starter for one indicator pattern
steps.body:
Write a small YARA rule to detect the sample (or a characteristic string) as a learning artifact.

Example skeleton:
```
rule Training_Malware_Sample {
  meta:
    author = "YourName"
    description = "Training rule based on extracted strings"
    date = "YYYY-MM-DD"
  strings:
    $s1 = "<unique_string_here>" ascii nocase
    $s2 = "<another_unique_string>" ascii
  condition:
    1 of them
}
```

Validation:
- Rule compiles and matches the sample (or matches extracted strings).

Deliverable:
- `evidence/notes/training.yar`

Troubleshooting:
- If it matches too broadly, tighten strings or require multiple conditions.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Write the SOC-style malware triage report
steps.body:
This is the portfolio gold.

Create/Update:
- `malware-triage-report.md`

Recommended sections:
1) Executive Summary (what it likely is, confidence)
2) Sample Details (hashes, file type)
3) Static Findings (strings, metadata)
4) Dynamic Findings (processes, persistence, network)
5) Indicators of Compromise (categorized)
6) MITRE ATT&CK mapping (optional)
7) Recommendations (containment, hunting queries ideas)
8) Limitations (sandbox evasion, no internet, etc.)

Validation:
- A reader can follow your steps and understand your conclusions.

Deliverables:
- Completed report + links to evidence paths inside the repo.

Troubleshooting:
- If youâ€™re unsure about conclusions, explicitly mark uncertain items and propose next steps (submit to sandbox, detonate with better telemetry, etc.).

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Cleanup: revert snapshot and confirm no persistence remains
steps.body:
After analysis:
- Revert VM to `CLEAN_BASELINE` snapshot.

Validation:
- System returns to known-clean state.

Deliverable:
- Note in README/report that the VM was reverted to baseline.

SOC Note:
- This models professional hygiene: malware labs reset after detonation.

You produced hash values (MD5/SHA1/SHA256) and captured file metadata
You extracted and categorized IOCs from static triage and (optional) dynamic telemetry

You wrote a clear triage report with findings, confidence, and recommendations

troubleshooting.issue: I canâ€™t safely get a malware sample
troubleshooting.fix: Use EICAR for workflow practice and document that this run is a triage exercise. Later, use a dedicated training platform or a known lab source with explicit permission.

troubleshooting.issue: The sample does nothing when executed
troubleshooting.fix: It may be sandbox-aware, require admin, need arguments, or be non-executable. Document the behavior, focus on static IOCs, and recommend next steps (richer sandbox telemetry, different VM profile).

troubleshooting.issue: Wireshark shows no traffic
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm correct interface, ensure capture started before execution, and confirm the VM has a network route. Some malware only beacons after delays or triggers.

troubleshooting.fix: Use filters: include Process Name = sample.exe; include Operation = CreateFile/RegSetValue/TCP Connect; exclude common Windows noise where safe. Focus on first minutes after execution.

troubleshooting.issue: Iâ€™m worried I infected my host
troubleshooting.fix: Stop, disconnect network, and revert snapshots. If you executed outside the VM, treat it as a real incident: isolate the host, run offline AV scans, and seek professional remediation.

home-security-lab.title: Home Security Lab (SOC Monitoring at Home)
tools: A spare PC or laptop (recommended) OR a VM host
Ubuntu Server (or Debian) for log collection
Windows machine (or Windows VM) as an endpoint
Splunk Free OR Elastic Stack (optional SIEM)

Comfort using Linux CLI
Basic familiarity with log files and event logs
Ability to create VMs or use spare hardware

deliverables: A documented home lab topology diagram (network layout)
A configured Linux log collector (rsyslog server)
Forwarded logs from at least one endpoint (Linux and/or Windows)
Baseline capture (ports/services + normal log patterns)
Detection test results (simulated brute force / scan / suspicious behavior)
Evidence artifacts (screenshots, logs, pcaps)
A SOC-style Home Monitoring Report (Markdown)

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Plan your home SOC topology (simple but realistic)
steps.body:
You are building a mini SOC environment, not just "installing tools."

Recommended minimum lab layout:
- 1 Linux Server (Log Collector)
- 1 Windows endpoint (Victim/Client)
- 1 Linux endpoint (optional)
- Your router (existing home network)

Two recommended setups:

Option A (Best / easiest): Virtual lab (VMs)
- Ubuntu Server VM = log collector
- Windows 10/11 VM = endpoint

Option B (More realistic): Spare laptop/PC as log collector
- Ubuntu Server installed on spare machine
- Windows PC is your real workstation

Deliverable:
- Create `Home-Security-Lab/evidence/notes/topology.md`
- Write a short topology description + IP ranges.

Validation:
- You can clearly explain which machine collects logs and which machine generates logs.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Create the evidence folder structure in the repo
steps.body:
In the CyberSecurity-Projects repo:

Commands:
- `cd ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/Home-Security-Lab`
- `mkdir -p evidence/screenshots evidence/logs evidence/pcaps evidence/notes evidence/iocs evidence/reports`

Create these files:
- `baseline.md`
- `detection-tests.md`
- `home-soc-report.md`

Validation:
- `ls -R evidence` shows your folder structure.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of folder tree.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Install and secure your Linux log collector server
steps.body:
Install Ubuntu Server (recommended).

Update the system:
- `sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y`

Install core tools:
- `sudo apt install -y ufw rsyslog net-tools curl wget unzip fail2ban`

Enable SSH (if not installed):
- `sudo apt install -y openssh-server`

Check SSH:
- `sudo systemctl status ssh`

Validation:
- SSH service is active.
- Server has a stable IP address.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of `ip a` output
- Screenshot of `systemctl status ssh`

Troubleshooting:
- If you cannot SSH in, confirm firewall is not blocking port 22 and the VM network is correct.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Configure a static IP or DHCP reservation for the log collector
steps.body:
Your collector must be reachable.

Recommended approach:
- Set DHCP reservation in your router for the Ubuntu server.

Alternative:
- Configure static IP in Ubuntu netplan.

Check current IP:
- `ip a`

Write down:
- Server IP
- Gateway IP
- DNS

Deliverable:
- Add IP info to `evidence/notes/topology.md`

Validation:
- Collector keeps the same IP after reboot.

Troubleshooting:
- If IP changes, fix DHCP reservation or configure static IP.

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Configure UFW firewall rules on the collector
steps.body:
Lock down the collector.

Enable UFW:
- `sudo ufw default deny incoming`
- `sudo ufw default allow outgoing`

Allow SSH:
- `sudo ufw allow 22/tcp`

Allow syslog (UDP 514 is common):
- `sudo ufw allow 514/udp`

Enable firewall:
- `sudo ufw enable`

Verify:
- `sudo ufw status verbose`

Validation:
- UFW is active.
- SSH still works.

Deliverable:
- Screenshot of `ufw status verbose`

Troubleshooting:
- If SSH breaks, use the VM console to re-allow port 22.

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Configure rsyslog to receive remote logs
steps.body:
rsyslog is installed by default on Ubuntu, but remote receiving is usually disabled.

Edit rsyslog config:
- `sudo nano /etc/rsyslog.conf`

Uncomment or add these lines:
```
module(load="imudp")
input(type="imudp" port="514")

module(load="imtcp")
input(type="imtcp" port="514")
```

Restart rsyslog:
- `sudo systemctl restart rsyslog`

Check status:
- `sudo systemctl status rsyslog`

Validation:
- rsyslog service is active.
- Port is listening:
  - `sudo ss -tulnp | grep 514`

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of `ss -tulnp | grep 514`

Troubleshooting:
- If port 514 is not listening, confirm the lines are not commented and restart the service.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Configure Linux logging structure for incoming logs
steps.body:
By default, incoming logs may mix with system logs. Create a clean folder.

Create a directory:
- `sudo mkdir -p /var/log/remote`
- `sudo chmod 755 /var/log/remote`

Create an rsyslog rule:
- `sudo nano /etc/rsyslog.d/10-remote.conf`

Add:
```
$template RemoteLogs,"/var/log/remote/%HOSTNAME%/%PROGRAMNAME%.log"
*.* ?RemoteLogs
& stop
```

Restart rsyslog:
- `sudo systemctl restart rsyslog`

Validation:
- Directory exists.
- rsyslog restarted successfully.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of `/var/log/remote` existing

Troubleshooting:
- If logs do not appear later, check permissions and confirm rsyslog is writing.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Forward logs from a Linux endpoint (test client)
steps.body:
You need at least one endpoint sending logs.

On your Linux endpoint machine (or a second VM):

Edit rsyslog config:
- `sudo nano /etc/rsyslog.conf`

Add at bottom:
```
*.* @<COLLECTOR_IP>:514
```

Use @@ for TCP:
```
*.* @@<COLLECTOR_IP>:514
```

Restart:
- `sudo systemctl restart rsyslog`

Generate a test log entry:
- `logger "HOME SOC TEST: Linux endpoint connected"`

On collector:
- `sudo ls -R /var/log/remote`

Validation:
- You see logs arriving in `/var/log/remote/<hostname>/...`

Deliverables:
- Screenshot showing the test log on the collector.

Troubleshooting:
- If logs do not arrive:
  - ping the collector
  - check UFW allows 514
  - check rsyslog listening on collector (`ss -tulnp | grep 514`)
  - check client config syntax

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Forward logs from Windows (Sysmon recommended)
steps.body:
Windows is where this lab becomes real.

Two options:

Option A (Basic): Windows Event Logs only
- Use Windows Event Forwarding or an agent (harder)

Option B (Recommended): Install Sysmon + forward logs using an agent (Splunk Forwarder or Winlogbeat)

Sysmon:
- Download Sysmon from Microsoft Sysinternals
- Install with a config (SwiftOnSecurity config is commonly used)

Example install command (Admin PowerShell):
- `sysmon64.exe -accepteula -i sysmonconfig.xml`

If using Splunk Forwarder (recommended if you're already using Splunk in your other project):
- Install Universal Forwarder
- Configure to forward Windows Event Logs to Splunk

Validation:
- Sysmon service running
- Event logs show process creation events

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of Sysmon installed
- Screenshot of a Sysmon Event ID 1 (process creation)

Troubleshooting:
- If Sysmon doesn't log: confirm the service is running and config file is valid.

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Establish a baseline: ports, services, and normal log behavior
steps.body:
Baseline means: "What does normal look like?"

On your collector:
- `sudo ss -tulnp`
- `sudo journalctl -n 50`

From your attacker machine (or Kali VM), scan your Windows endpoint:
- `nmap -sV <WINDOWS_IP>`

Record:
- Normal open ports
- Normal DNS behavior
- Normal authentication events

Save baseline output:
- `nmap -sV <WINDOWS_IP> | tee evidence/logs/nmap-baseline.txt`

Validation:
- You can identify which ports are expected and why.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/logs/nmap-baseline.txt`
- `baseline.md` updated with notes

Troubleshooting:
- If nmap fails, check firewall settings or VM network mode.

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Run detection test #1: brute-force simulation (safe)
steps.body:
Simulate a brute-force style pattern safely.

Linux endpoint brute force simulation:
- Try repeated invalid SSH logins from another machine.

Example:
- `ssh fakeuser@<LINUX_ENDPOINT_IP>`
- Enter wrong password multiple times.

On collector:
- Inspect logs:
  - `sudo grep -i "failed" -R /var/log/remote | tail -n 50`

Validation:
- You can see repeated failed auth attempts.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of log entries
- Notes in `detection-tests.md`

Troubleshooting:
- If logs donâ€™t show, confirm forwarding works and that your log rule is writing correctly.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Run detection test #2: port scan simulation
steps.body:
Port scanning is a realistic SOC detection scenario.

From Kali or another machine:
- `nmap -sS -T4 <WINDOWS_IP>`
- `nmap -sS -T4 <LINUX_IP>`

On the endpoints:
- Look for firewall or system logs.

On collector:
- Search for scan patterns:
  - `sudo grep -R "nmap" /var/log/remote | tail -n 50`

Optional Wireshark capture:
- Start capture during scan and save to `evidence/pcaps/portscan-test.pcapng`

Validation:
- You captured evidence of the scan in logs and/or pcap.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/pcaps/portscan-test.pcapng`
- screenshot of scan output

Troubleshooting:
- If nothing logs, that's a learning moment: document that your current setup lacks IDS capability.

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Optional hardening: install fail2ban and confirm bans work
steps.body:
fail2ban simulates real SOC defensive automation.

Install:
- `sudo apt install -y fail2ban`

Enable:
- `sudo systemctl enable --now fail2ban`

Check status:
- `sudo fail2ban-client status`

Validation:
- fail2ban is running.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of fail2ban status

Troubleshooting:
- If no jails appear, configure a jail for sshd in `/etc/fail2ban/jail.local`.

steps.title: Step 14 â€” Optional SIEM: ingest logs into Splunk (recommended)
steps.body:
If you already have Splunk from your Log-Analysis project, this is the best upgrade.

Option A: Install Splunk on the collector
Option B: Forward rsyslog logs into Splunk

Typical approach:
- Configure Splunk to monitor `/var/log/remote/**`

Example (Splunk inputs.conf concept):
- Monitor directory
- Assign sourcetype = syslog

Validation:
- You can search logs in Splunk:
  - `index=* host=<endpoint>`

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of Splunk search results
- Screenshot of a simple dashboard panel

Troubleshooting:
- If logs donâ€™t ingest, confirm file permissions and Splunk monitoring path.

steps.title: Step 15 â€” Build a simple detection checklist (SOC workflow)
steps.body:
Create a repeatable daily SOC workflow.

Create `evidence/notes/monitoring-checklist.md` with:
- Daily authentication failures review
- Daily new IP/domain review
- Weekly port scan / service inventory
- System update review
- New device discovery

Example log search commands:
- `sudo grep -R "Failed password" /var/log/remote | tail -n 50`
- `sudo grep -R "Accepted password" /var/log/remote | tail -n 50`

Validation:
- You can run the checklist and explain what each item detects.

Deliverable:
- Completed monitoring checklist file.

steps.title: Step 16 â€” Write the Home SOC Report (portfolio-ready)
steps.body:
Write your final report in:
- `home-soc-report.md`

Recommended structure:
1) Executive Summary
2) Lab Topology
3) Log Collection Setup (rsyslog + forwarding)
4) Baseline Findings
5) Detection Tests (brute force, scan)
6) Observed Indicators
7) Gaps Identified (no IDS, no EDR, etc.)
8) Improvements Roadmap

Validation:
- A reader can replicate your lab.

Deliverables:
- Final report + evidence paths.

Troubleshooting:
- If your lab feels "too simple," that's fine. The report should clearly identify the next upgrades (IDS project comes next).

successCriteria: You configured a Linux log collector with rsyslog listening on port 514
You forwarded logs from at least one Linux endpoint into /var/log/remote/
You documented a baseline (nmap scan + normal logs) for your environment

You produced a topology diagram/description and a SOC-style report
You saved all artifacts into the repo under Home-Security-Lab/evidence/

troubleshooting.fix: Confirm ping works, confirm UFW allows 514/udp, confirm rsyslog is listening (`ss -tulnp | grep 514`), and confirm endpoint rsyslog config uses correct IP and syntax.

troubleshooting.issue: Port 514 is listening but logs still donâ€™t write into /var/log/remote
troubleshooting.fix: Check your rsyslog rule in `/etc/rsyslog.d/10-remote.conf` and confirm the directory permissions allow writing. Restart rsyslog.

troubleshooting.issue: Windows logs are hard to forward
troubleshooting.fix: Use Sysmon + Splunk Forwarder or Winlogbeat. Windows Event Forwarding works but is more complex. Document whichever approach you used.

troubleshooting.issue: SSH brute-force test doesnâ€™t show up
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm the endpoint is logging auth attempts (check `/var/log/auth.log`) and confirm those logs are forwarded.

Basic understanding of ports and networking
Basic Docker knowledge (images, containers, ports)
Comfort editing config files (nano/vim)
docker-security-lab.objective: Build a realistic Docker security lab by deploying DVWA (or Juice Shop), identifying insecure configurations, scanning containers for vulnerabilities, applying hardening steps (least privilege, network segmentation, firewalling), and documenting the results like a SOC analyst.

Evidence screenshots + CLI outputs
Final SOC-style Docker Security Lab report (Markdown)

steps.title: Step 1 â€” Create the repo structure and evidence folders
steps.body:
Navigate to the project folder:

- `cd ~/CyberSecurity-Projects/Docker-Security-Lab`

Create evidence folders:

- `mkdir -p evidence/screenshots evidence/logs evidence/reports evidence/notes evidence/scans evidence/pcaps`

Create your main report file:

- `touch docker-security-report.md`

Deliverable:
- Save a screenshot of your folder structure.

Validation:
- `ls -R evidence` shows the expected folders.

steps.title: Step 2 â€” Install Docker + Docker Compose
steps.body:
Update packages:

- `sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y`

Install prerequisites:

- `sudo apt install -y ca-certificates curl gnupg lsb-release`

Install Docker:

- `sudo apt install -y docker.io`

Enable Docker:

- `sudo systemctl enable --now docker`

Verify:

- `docker --version`
- `docker compose version` (or `docker-compose --version`)

If docker compose is missing:

- `sudo apt install -y docker-compose`

Add your user to docker group:

- `sudo usermod -aG docker $USER`

Then log out and back in.

Validation:
- `docker run hello-world` works without sudo.

Troubleshooting:
- If you get permission denied: log out/in or run `newgrp docker`.

steps.title: Step 3 â€” Build the vulnerable app lab using Docker Compose
steps.body:
Weâ€™ll use DVWA as the default target.

Inside the project folder, create a compose file:

- `nano docker-compose.yml`

Paste:

```yaml
version: "3.8"

services:
  dvwa:
    image: vulnerables/web-dvwa
    container_name: dvwa
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "8080:80"
    networks:
      - labnet

networks:
  labnet:
    driver: bridge
```

Start it:

- `docker compose up -d`

Check status:

- `docker ps`

Validation:
- DVWA is running and listening on port 8080.
- Visit: `http://<YOUR_SERVER_IP>:8080`

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of DVWA running
- Save output of `docker ps` to:
  - `evidence/logs/docker-ps-before.txt`

Command:
- `docker ps > evidence/logs/docker-ps-before.txt`

Troubleshooting:
- If the site wonâ€™t load, check firewall rules and confirm port mapping.

steps.title: Step 4 â€” Identify exposed ports and map the attack surface
steps.body:
Your job as a SOC analyst is to document exposure.

Check open ports locally:

- `sudo ss -tulnp`

Scan from another machine (recommended):

- `nmap -sV <SERVER_IP>`

Save scan output:

- `nmap -sV <SERVER_IP> | tee evidence/logs/nmap-scan-before.txt`

Validation:
- You confirm port 8080 is exposed.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/logs/nmap-scan-before.txt`
- Notes written into:
  - `evidence/notes/attack-surface.md`

steps.title: Step 5 â€” Inspect the container configuration (baseline security review)
steps.body:
Collect baseline information before hardening.

Inspect container:

- `docker inspect dvwa > evidence/logs/docker-inspect-dvwa.json`

Check container user:

- `docker exec -it dvwa whoami`

Check running processes:

- `docker exec -it dvwa ps aux`

Check environment variables:

- `docker exec -it dvwa env | head -n 30`

Validation:
- You have baseline evidence showing DVWA runs as root (likely).

Deliverables:
- `docker-inspect-dvwa.json`
- Screenshot of `whoami` output

Troubleshooting:
- If exec fails, confirm container name is correct (`docker ps`).

steps.title: Step 6 â€” Perform container vulnerability scanning with Trivy
steps.body:
Trivy is a major resume-grade tool for container security.

Install Trivy:

- `sudo apt install -y wget`
- `wget https://github.com/aquasecurity/trivy/releases/latest/download/trivy_0.51.1_Linux-64bit.deb`
- `sudo dpkg -i trivy_0.51.1_Linux-64bit.deb`

(Version may change. If install fails, use official docs.)

Scan DVWA image:

- `trivy image vulnerables/web-dvwa | tee evidence/scans/trivy-dvwa-before.txt`

Validation:
- You capture vulnerabilities and severity output.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/scans/trivy-dvwa-before.txt`

Troubleshooting:
- If Trivy fails due to DB download, retry or confirm internet access.

steps.title: Step 7 â€” Apply basic host hardening (firewall + least exposure)
steps.body:
Hardening begins with limiting access.

Enable UFW:

- `sudo ufw default deny incoming`
- `sudo ufw default allow outgoing`

Allow SSH:

- `sudo ufw allow 22/tcp`

Allow DVWA only for your LAN subnet (recommended):

Example if your LAN is 192.168.1.0/24:

- `sudo ufw allow from 192.168.1.0/24 to any port 8080 proto tcp`

Enable firewall:

- `sudo ufw enable`

Check:

- `sudo ufw status verbose | tee evidence/logs/ufw-status.txt`

Validation:
- DVWA is accessible only from LAN.

Deliverables:
- `ufw-status.txt`

Troubleshooting:
- If you lock yourself out, use VM console access to re-allow SSH.

steps.title: Step 8 â€” Add Docker network segmentation and isolate services
steps.body:
Right now DVWA is exposed directly to your host network.

You will now build a segmented setup:

- Internal network for the vulnerable app
- Reverse proxy (optional)

For now, confirm your network:

- `docker network ls`
- `docker network inspect docker-security-lab_labnet > evidence/logs/docker-network-labnet.json`

Validation:
- You can show the bridge network configuration.

Deliverables:
- `docker-network-labnet.json`

Notes:
- Document what segmentation means in Docker (internal networks prevent external exposure).

steps.title: Step 9 â€” Apply container hardening (drop privileges + read-only FS)
steps.body:
This is where the lab becomes advanced.

Update your `docker-compose.yml` to include:

- read_only filesystem
- dropped capabilities
- no-new-privileges

Edit file:

- `nano docker-compose.yml`

Example hardened config:

```yaml
version: "3.8"

services:
  dvwa:
    image: vulnerables/web-dvwa
    container_name: dvwa
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "8080:80"
    networks:
      - labnet
    read_only: true
    security_opt:
      - no-new-privileges:true
    cap_drop:
      - ALL

networks:
  labnet:
    driver: bridge
```

Restart:

- `docker compose down`
- `docker compose up -d`

Validation:
- DVWA still runs.
- You successfully hardened the container.

Deliverables:
- Screenshot of updated compose file
- `docker ps` output saved to `evidence/logs/docker-ps-after.txt`

Troubleshooting:
- If DVWA breaks: document what failed. Many vulnerable apps require write access.
- This is still a win: it proves security hardening can break insecure apps.
- Roll back selectively (remove read_only or allow tmpfs volumes).

steps.title: Step 10 â€” Add logging and monitoring for container activity
steps.body:
SOC work = visibility.

Check Docker logs:

- `docker logs dvwa | tail -n 50`

Save logs:

- `docker logs dvwa > evidence/logs/dvwa-container-logs.txt`

Optional: enable JSON log driver (default is usually json-file).

Inspect logging config:

- `docker inspect dvwa | grep -i log -n`

Validation:
- You have evidence of container logs and HTTP requests.

Deliverables:
- `dvwa-container-logs.txt`

Troubleshooting:
- If logs are empty, generate traffic by loading DVWA in browser.

steps.title: Step 11 â€” Perform a basic attack simulation and observe evidence
steps.body:
Do a safe simulated attack.

From another machine:

- `curl -I http://<SERVER_IP>:8080`

Try fuzzing-style requests:

- `curl "http://<SERVER_IP>:8080/index.php?id=1'"`

Watch logs:

- `docker logs dvwa --since 5m | tail -n 100`

Optional: capture traffic with tcpdump:

- `sudo apt install -y tcpdump`
- `sudo tcpdump -i any port 8080 -w evidence/pcaps/dvwa-traffic.pcap`

Stop capture after 30â€“60 seconds.

Validation:
- You captured evidence of web requests.

Deliverables:
- `evidence/pcaps/dvwa-traffic.pcap`
- Screenshot of curl requests

Troubleshooting:
- If tcpdump file is empty, confirm correct interface or use `-i any`.

steps.title: Step 12 â€” Re-run vulnerability scanning after hardening
steps.body:
Even after hardening, vulnerabilities remain in the image.

Run Trivy again:

- `trivy image vulnerables/web-dvwa | tee evidence/scans/trivy-dvwa-after.txt`

Compare before vs after:
- Image vulnerabilities likely unchanged
- But runtime hardening reduces exploitation risk

Validation:
- You can explain why scanning doesn't change even if runtime security improves.

Deliverables:
- `trivy-dvwa-after.txt`
- Notes in `evidence/notes/vulnerability-summary.md`

steps.title: Step 13 â€” Write your Docker Security Report (portfolio-grade)
steps.body:
Write your final report:

- `docker-security-report.md`

Recommended structure:

1) Executive Summary
2) Lab Setup (Docker + Compose)
3) Deployment (DVWA container)
4) Baseline Attack Surface (nmap, ports)
5) Vulnerability Scan Results (Trivy)
6) Hardening Steps Applied
   - firewall
   - reduced exposure
   - capabilities dropped
   - read-only filesystem attempt
7) Monitoring Evidence (docker logs, pcap)
8) Detection Observations
9) Lessons Learned
10) Next Improvements
   - WAF
   - reverse proxy
   - IDS/Suricata
   - SIEM ingestion

Validation:
- A reader could reproduce your lab.

Deliverables:
- Completed report with evidence paths and screenshots.

steps.title: Step 14 â€” Optional upgrade path (Juice Shop + IDS + SIEM)
steps.body:
This lab becomes a full SOC playground if you extend it.

Optional upgrades:

A) Add OWASP Juice Shop
- Deploy as second service
- Compare attack surface

B) Add Suricata IDS (ties into IDS_Setup project)
- Monitor traffic to port 8080

C) Forward logs into Splunk
- Ingest docker logs and syslog

Deliverable:
- Add a section to your report called "Future Work" listing these upgrades.

Validation:
- Your lab now connects directly to your planned IDS project.

You captured baseline container configuration evidence (docker inspect)
You performed vulnerability scanning with Trivy and saved results
You applied at least two hardening techniques (UFW restriction, dropped capabilities, no-new-privileges, etc.)
You captured monitoring evidence (docker logs and/or tcpdump pcap)
You produced a professional Docker Security Lab report stored in the repo

troubleshooting.issue: Docker commands fail with permission denied
troubleshooting.fix: Run `sudo usermod -aG docker $USER` then log out/in. Alternatively use sudo temporarily.

troubleshooting.issue: DVWA container runs but site is not reachable
troubleshooting.fix: Confirm port mapping in compose file (8080:80). Run `sudo ss -tulnp | grep 8080`. Confirm UFW rules allow the port from your LAN.

troubleshooting.issue: Trivy install fails due to version mismatch
troubleshooting.fix: Use the official Trivy install instructions from Aqua Security and install via apt repository instead of .deb.

troubleshooting.issue: Adding read_only and cap_drop breaks DVWA
troubleshooting.fix: Document the failure as part of the security lesson. Remove read_only first, then re-test. Some vulnerable apps require write access and elevated privileges.

troubleshooting.issue: tcpdump capture is empty
troubleshooting.fix: Use `-i any` and confirm traffic is flowing by refreshing DVWA in browser. Ensure correct port (8080).

runbooks.title: Alert Triage (first 5 min)
steps: Open the alert and note source, time, and type.
Check if the asset/user is critical (VIP, prod server).
Look up source IP or hash in IOC Helper or threat intel.
If clearly false positive, document and close; otherwise assign or escalate.

runbooks.title: Escalate to L2
steps: Document what you've done: logs reviewed, IOCs checked, timeline.
Summarize why escalation is needed (e.g. confirmed malicious, scope unknown).
Assign to L2 queue or tag per your org process.
Add handoff notes so L2 can continue without re-doing triage.

runbooks.title: Phishing â€“ Initial Triage
steps: Preserve the email (forward as attachment, don't reply).
Extract URLs and sender; check in VirusTotal/URL scanners.
Identify affected users and whether anyone clicked or entered credentials.
If credentials entered: trigger password reset and notify; escalate.

runbooks.title: Malware â€“ Isolate Host
steps: Confirm the host (hostname, IP) and that isolation is authorized.
Use EDR or network tool to isolate (disable NIC or move to VLAN).
Capture a memory/disk snapshot if your process allows.
Document and hand to forensics or L2 for analysis.

runbooks.title: Splunk â€“ Run a saved search
steps: Open Splunk and go to Search & Reporting (or your app).
Open the saved search from the list or run the SPL from the Cheatbook.
Set the time range (e.g. Last 24 hours).
Review results; export to CSV or add to a dashboard if needed.

runbooks.title: Phishing â€” Initial Triage
steps: Confirm the report source and preserve the original message (don't forward inline).
Extract key artifacts: sender, reply-to, URLs, attachments, and header anomalies.
Check URLs/domains and attachment hashes with at least two intel sources.
Assess impact: who received it, who clicked, and whether credentials were entered.
Contain if needed: block sender/domain/URL and reset credentials for affected users.
Document findings using the Incident Report template and note follow-up actions.

runbooks.title: Suspicious Login / Brute Force â€” Triage
steps: Identify the affected account(s), source IP(s), and timeframe.
Look for patterns: repeated failures followed by success, impossible travel, new device/UA.
Check IP reputation and whether it's a known corporate/VPN range.
Scope the blast radius: other accounts targeted from same IP or same account from many IPs.
Contain: reset credentials, force session logout, and block IP if appropriate.
Document evidence and recommendation (true positive vs false positive) with confidence.

runbooks.title: IOC Enrichment â€” Fast Workflow
steps: Classify the indicator (IP/domain/URL/hash/email) and capture the source context.
Check at least two intel sources and record dates, detections, and supporting notes.
Decide verdict: benign / suspicious / malicious and state confidence level.
If suspicious/malicious, map to a plausible technique (MITRE) and note likely intent.
Recommend action: block, monitor, or close as false positive with justification.
Save a short evidence table in the ticket notes or incident report template.

runbooks.title: Splunk â€” Run a Saved Search & Validate Results
steps: Locate the saved search and confirm its intended purpose and schedule.
Run it for a recent time window and verify the fields it relies on exist.
Spot-check a handful of events to confirm they match the detection intent.
Adjust timeframe and filters to confirm it triggers only on relevant activity.
Document the query, expected output, and one example event in the case notes.
If it's noisy, propose a refinement (threshold, allowlist, additional field constraints).
